reviewText: This is an absolutely fantastic action/suspense movie, the acting is great, the story pulls you in, and I really couldn't tell what was going to happen next at any point! I went in to it expecting an average modern movie with all the same parts that I regret spending money on, but this is going to be the first movie in a long time I will buy on DVD the day it comes out! The plot, the idea is just all around great and let me tell you - I left wishing I was a thousand times more productive! Since seeing it, I feel like I could be Bradley Cooper's character if I put in the effort - and that's something that pops into my head occasionally, so this movie clearly had a major impact on me!

Limitless is a great idea for a movie.  The idea of acquiring fantastic mental powers by simply taking a pill is probably appealing to most of us. The urge to be a genius instead of limited selves is a nice fantasy.  This is exactly where Eddie Mora (Bradley Cooper) finds himself.  Eddie begins the film as a perennial looser. He has an advance to write a book but can't find a way to begin or even articulate what the book is about.  Enter Eddie's sleazy former brother-in-law Vernon (Johnny Whitworth) who has a pill that allows people to access 100% of their brain.

(Some Spoiler Below)
One doze of the drug (randomly named NZT-48 and definitely not FDA approved) allows Eddie to begin writing a fantastic book and is able to recall things long buried in his memory.  Eddie wants more of the drug and shows up at Vernon's apartment first a little beaten up then very dead and his apartment turned upside down.  Clearly, someone was looking for the NZT - but did they find it?  Eddie starts looking and just as he is about to give up, he discovers a bag filled with pills, money and a notebook with the names of clients.  With the drug, Eddie turns his life around.  He completes his book, becomes a successful investor and the love of his girlfriend Lindsey.  He is noticed by Carl van Loon (nicely played by Robert De Nero) who is a Warren Buffett-like mover and shaker.

The story becomes cautionary. Eddie takes more of the NZT than he should and soon begins to experience period when the Hyde part of his personality takes over. He can't remember where he has been or what he has done.  He meets his once brilliant ex-wife who burned out taking the drug and we find out the taking it can lead to severe illness and death. So, who else is on NZT?
(End Spoilers)

Barry Cooper plays Eddie as a likeable average guy who has nothing but problems.  The drug eliminates his obstacles and he becomes dangerously overconfident as he learns Italian in minutes to impress a woman and understands complex financial data but simply looking at it. Limitless has a lot of suspense as Eddie's life becomes more complicated and he is threatened by someone who clearly knows he has the drug and then by a Russian loan shark named Gennady. Robert De Nero is his professional best in the supporting part of Carl Van Loon, who is impressed with Eddie but also has some reservations.  Abbie Cornish is good as Eddie's girlfriend and Andrew Howard makes an effective villain as Gennady.  The CG work that fills in Eddie's experience when he looses control of the drug pulls and twists what he sees effectively. Anyone who gets motion sickness easily will want to look away.

Some reviewers wanted to have more of De Nero in the film but his role was not especially prominent.  The movie is well paced and holds your attention from the start. Limitless is worth a look and probably is even better the second time around.

I regret seeing Limitless! The violence is excessive and disturbing. PG-13 doesn't mean very much anymore! The current movie rating system in the United States is an absolute joke and it should be abolished!  Have a sex/violence activity rating system like they do on Common Sense Media! At least that would be much more honest! When stabbing out a man's eye and making him blind (he was already blind in the other eye) is PG-13, then what's next? Scraping it out with a spoon?

This is a drug film. It came across as a not even thinly veiled ode to the greatness of Methamphedamine (Speed) and/or Cocaine. Its compleatly unashamed in its message and it doesn't take one step back from it all the way to the end. The message is that drugs are great and that all the risks can be managed by a smart addict. All the scifi aspects of the film do is serve to exaggerate the real-world boost of drugs.

All the hallmarks are here. The world becomes brighter when the drug is taken. He goes and parties continuously for days. He can crank out work. He suddenly starts cleaning his apartment compulsively in the middle of the night. he forgets to eat. He does damage to his body. He has blackouts. His woman friend who was on the drug for a long time is now prematurely aged. We even get the guys drug dealer disguised as a high-interest loan shark. And you get large numbers of contemporaries dying. There is even all the addict paranoia about hiding and losing a pile of drugs. They also have him so in love with his drugs that he literally licks them off the floor.

And best of all, they use two professions in the film where drug use is rather common (wall street and writers).

But what the film gets wrong is that drugs don't make people smarter or teach them foreign languages instantly. They speed you up and give you limitless energy and make you more confident. You can get more done, but not because your smarter. But because you can work 2x to 3x longer.

Where the film falls down is in showing the long-term price. It didn't show his body wearing out. It didn't show the paranoia or the teeth falling out. It didn't show that as drug use goes on you get diminishing returns. You may be able to crank out pages in a book, but they cease to be good pages. They also miss the costs of not being able to properly sleep.

On the positive side, right up to the happy ending its probably one of the best films I can think of in capturing the deluded mentality of a new heavy drug addict. But its not generally a good message to be out pushing. And the film doesn't capture at all what happens in the long term.

The plans of the main character are fairly lame. He wants to get rich on wall street and the become president. Why? He has a plan to make everything better. And typical of drug logic, we never find out what that plan is. I also don't remember if we ever found out if he had or had not killed a woman during a blackout. But he clearly is involved in the murder of a lawyer for messing with his stash.

I could have lived with the film minus the happy ending. But ending it in the way they did made a pro-drug film.

Robert De Niro is in the film basically doing a character actor role as the big man on wall street. Its a completely workmanlike performance. His name on a film still sells tickets but you really wonder how many times can get away with it putting his name on something he has no personal investment in.

Somebody came up with a new continous zoom effect for the film. Its an interesting effect and it communicates well to the viewer the sense of being trapping at full speed thats at the heart of the film. Its maybe used a little too much and they pulled it out way too early. But it was a nice original touch.

The film is essentially told from the narrative point of view of the main character. Bradley Cooper pulls it off well. His girlfriend is basically a prop character.

Technically and in terms of acting, its a good film. But the script and its message are rather questionable.

Mostly, films go in one side of my head and right out the other.  If I can remember a film I saw Friday, on Monday, that's unusual.

It's been a couple weeks since I saw this.  It's still there in my memory.

I think there are several reasons, not necessarily in order of importance:

1) The opening credits are worth the price of admission on their own.  Whatever you were thinking when you sat down in the theater, you're transported immediately to somewhere else... wherever that will turn out to be.  Amazing and outstanding!

2) The overall plot is Hitchcock-esque.  You don't know what's going to happen, and cliches are out the window.  As the story builds, the suspense is palpable.

3) The visuals... This isn't on the scale of an AVATAR, but parts of it approach The Matrix.  This movie is really a trip-and-a-half.

4) The performances, and dramatic direction, are excellent, as are many other production factors, including music, that don't smack you in the face but which are indispensible to the experience.

5) The ending is entirely non-cliche and unpredictable.  Hitchcock would be proud to have directed it.

So, although it isn't populated with super-star actors and actresses (yet), this is a blockbuster, destined for cult fame and longevity.

The more I think about it, the more I like it.

A struggling writer takes a pill that enables the user to access the parts of the brain that are not utilized, allowing him to function at an extremely high level. It turns out that this is an untested narcotic, and has serious side effects. He is pursued by others who want to benefit from the drug. This was a very engaging and original storyline, with the identity of a man following the writer a true mystery until the story is concluding. The spectacle of an individual opening up his mind, enabling him to devise clever ways to endure, and also to reach an intellectual level previously unseen, is cool. Nice work on this one.

"Limitless" gets off to a strong start - a dicey character hands out "smart pills" that really work. Pop one, and you're suddenly brilliant. In the case of this down-and-out writer, that means not just getting started on that novel stalled because of writer's block, but finishing in just a few days. Of course, being that brilliant becomes addictive.

The story moves along well. First, his dealer ends up dead. (What would a smrt guy do with that clue?) Then,to finance his venture, he borrows from the local loan shark (not so smart). Next, he flaunts his new-found ability as day trader, building up his financial head of steam - and I have to wonder whether taking such a high profile so fast was really a good idea.

Things get out of hand, though. The loan shark gets his hands on the pill, and dicovers that being a smart crook is more fun than just being a crook. And there are side effects - the kind that kill not just you, but maybe other people, too ...

This should have been an August movie. Just a few too many things seem just a bit too implausible for anything but a silly season flick. But, if you stifle your own intelligence, it's enjoyable enough.

-- wiredweird

Sometimes movies have concepts so grand and large-scale that potential viewers can't help but imagine to themselves in advance what they would do with such technology, powers, knowledge, etc.  Imagine if you had the ability to travel through time.  What would you do?  When would you go?  Our imaginations are sparked, and thus, movies about time travel are often disappointing, because their reach never achieves what we'd imagine ourselves doing.

LIMITLESS suffers from this as well.  Bradley Cooper plays an author with a serious case of writer's block.  He's smart, but messy and disorganized.  He's handsome but can't be bothered to take care of his appearance.  And he can't get going on the book he's supposed to write.  His girlfriend (Abbie Cornish) is finally tired of him and leaves.  But hope arrives in the form of a new drug that he is given by a distant acquaintance.  It will allow him to access "100% of his brain."  Suddenly he's got phenomenal cognitive abilities...particularly the ability to take random scraps of past things he's encountered and to put them together into patterns that no one else can recognize.  It's like the chess player who can envision every possible move and the outcomes of each of those moves.  Cooper finishes his book (and it's brilliant) and then sets about making some serious money with his new powers.

With such incredible powers, he seems to strive to accomplish relatively little.  Yes, he wants to make money...that is certainly understandable and relatable.  But he doesn't see a big pattern for himself.  And as a viewer, I was constantly distracted by thinking..."wow, if I had HIS abilities, I'd do so much more."  It felt a little bit like a failure of the imagination on the part of the filmmakers.  Thus, I felt vaguely disappointed in the film...a great idea that boiled down to a somewhat predictable "corporate espionage" kind of thing.

Because Cooper discovers that this drug wasn't exactly developed with the approval of the FDA.  The side-effects, particularly of not taking the drug every day, are unpleasant.  And there are some unpleasant, even murderous folks who want the drug, or at least want the abilities that Cooper now has to work to their advantage.  Who can he trust?  How will he get away from all the folks who are now following him?  What will he do when his stock of pills runs out?

It's all interesting but a bit generic.  Cooper makes a pretty good leading man here, but he generates little chemistry with the bland Abbie Cornish...so we are not terribly invested in their relationship.  Robert DeNiro is on hand to collect a paycheck as a big shot executive trying to pull of the most ambitious corporate merger in history...and he needs the talent Cooper brings to the table.

The most amusing part of the movie is when Cooper has to borrow his initial stake in the stock market from a Russian loan shark, who inadvertently discovers the pill Cooper is taking.  Suddenly, this thuggish character becomes a LOT more dangerous to Cooper than the corporate big-shots.  This showed some creativity and the menace and humor of these scenes was welcome.

I recommend LIMITLESS, but my admiration is not...well...limitless.  Cooper is good.  The basic concept is intriguing.  The "action" shenanigans are fairly tense, but feel lifted from hundreds of movies that came before.  I realize this is a lazy thing to say, but I'd say wait until it comes out on DVD.

Have you ever been really intrigued by the concept of a film, but pretty much knew deep down that the movie would probably suck? That was my initial thought process going into Limitless. The concept of a drug (NZT) actually being able to unlock the maximum capacity of a person's brain with unlimited potential is extremely fascinating to me. Maybe it's because Bradley Cooper has mostly been in subpar films or the fact that Robert De Niro has been giving us "okay" to "what the hell happened to De Niro?" performances for over a decade, but trailers for Limitless just left you feeling empty like you knew ahead of time that they were going to blow it somehow. Surprisingly enough, Limitless isn't half as bad as expected and may be slightly better than you think.

The camera work is probably the first thing you'll notice as the opening credits use a unique zoom-in technique that mostly has us traveling through the back windshield of a countless number of cars in the type of traffic you'd expect in New York. This zoom-in technique is used several times throughout the film and, to be honest, makes you a little nauseous. As intriguing as it was, it actually wound up making me feel like I was just trapped on a carousel stuck on full speed. The use of color was a nice touch, as well. Whenever somebody first used NZT, the world became brighter. It was like they were seeing the world through a new set of eyes. The choreography went on to stand out a few more times throughout the film, as well. When Eddie (Cooper) finally sits down to write his novel, letters begin to rain down from his ceiling. When he first starts the stock market game, he glances up at his ceiling at one point and the tiles begin flipping around as Eddie sees the stock market play out on his ceiling. Things like that were a nice touch to make what would otherwise be an ordinary scene more memorable.

The cast seemed rather lukewarm though. Bradley Cooper seemed to give the strongest performance of the bunch, but that's probably because we spend the most time with his Eddie Morra character. Hearing Eddie's narrative throughout the film managed to add a bit more depth though. Hearing his thought process and him voicing how he felt helped add a little to the film and his character. Abbie Cornish and Robert De Niro were really disappointing though. Cornish was able to display fear in one scene and basically came off as indecisive the rest of the time while seemingly just going through the motions. Robert De Niro has one scene that's fairly memorable; the scene where his character, Carl Van Loon, gives his "don't make me your competition" speech. It honestly just seemed like De Niro was grossly misused the entire film while Van Loon felt like a watered down version of De Niro's Senator McLaughlin character in Machete without any sort of ridiculous fun injected into him.

The film did seem a little slow to get the ball rolling, but is pretty decent once it picks up around the halfway point. Any film that gets the wheels turning in your head because of its concept or makes you think about what you'd do in their shoes while using this fictitious product isn't all bad, in my book. Films that make you think can be a good thing even if it's something entirely different from what's taking place on-screen. There is one scene involving blood that'll probably make you want to puke. If you were in Eddie's situation, you'd probably do the same thing. But in the meantime, it's really...REALLY disgusting.

The biggest downfall for Limitless is that its concept is almost bigger than the rest of the film. The film is centered around this fantastic idea that doesn't seem to be fleshed out to its maximum potential. The final product though isn't all bad. With an intriguing storyline, a strong performance from Bradley Cooper, and some fairly captivating cinematography, Limitless comes off as an above average thriller that you won't feel entirely cheated on seeing that rainy day you decide to see it since nothing else looks good.

A blocked writer (played by Bradley Cooper) with average intelligence and a very low drive for success comes into possession of an unreleased drug that makes him a super genius. The movie's premise is that we only use a very small percentage of our brains, and the drug gets the body to use 100% of the brain.

In the movie, the writer only has a limited supply of the drug with no way to get more. The plot thickens since the drug has side effects and others are after his supply.

If I could give half stars, I'd give this movie a 4 1/2. It was very good, and definitely worth seeing, but there have been some movies more deserving of the full 5 stars. Still, this movie has a lot going for it. Here what's good:

1. The premise of this movie is unique. It's a great fantasy. Who wouldn't want that level of smarts. He's able to protect himself, make a killing on Wall Street and even impress women by ordering dinner speaking Italian. Just pop a pill and you're able to pretty much conquer the world. Great concept.

2. I like movies with smart heroes. This movie has that - well sometimes. The trouble with our hero is that without the drug he's an average guy who's sincere but not all that interesting, smart or even very likable. And when he's on the drug he's almost all about making money and having fun.

In the characters favor, he does sincerely love a woman, and he honestly wants to be the better man she needs and deserves. Or at least to appear that way.

Regardless of his flaws, the movie pulls you in, and you'll care about Bradley's character. This is usually essential for a movie to be good, and this movie succeeds in that. Cooper does an excellent job portraying the character in all his states.

3. This is not a special effects movie, but the cinematography and special effects were really well done. They were a major part of moving the story along, helping you understand what was happening to Bradley Cooper's character, and helping you get inside his head.

4. There was some suspense, action and danger that made the story exciting. The fact that the drug was going to run out and had dangerous side effects worked similar to a ticking bomb, always in the back of your mind. The movie kept to a good pace. It was almost always interesting and sometimes exciting. There were interesting plot twists. You don't always know what's coming next.

Here's what's not quite as good:

1. I wanted to like the lead character even more. I didn't quite identify with him personally. However others might.

2. I would have liked the love story to have been more developed. I think it would resulted in pulling the audience into the story in a more intense way.

3. Of course De Niro is an amazing actor, however his role was kind of small and not particularly high impact. I don't think the role was a great fit for him.

Regardless, I'd definitely recommend this movie. It's exciting and interesting, and I'd watch it again. Anyone who likes sci-fi, thrillers and suspense will want to check this movie out.

3/5  LIMITLESS is a slick, rollercoaster ride of a movie. It bowls the viewer along, heading with unapologetic alacrity and absurdity towards a goal it never quite reaches. Its the Hollywood equivalent of junk food. There are many glaring inconsistencies in the script but it doesnt really matter  just disengage your power of reasoning and enjoy the ride. The cast are accomplished, if a little underwhelming, although Cooper is quite impressive in the lead role. The concept is interesting but the script flounders somewhat in its attempt to explore the consequences of Morras astonishing, chemically-fuelled intellect and instead falls back on rather predictable abuse-of-power tropes. While this is an entertaining film, and it never bores for a moment, it does not bear close scrutiny and is instantly forgettable once seen.
The "Digital Copy" is not Vudu but actually just "copy to PC". For what I paid it was not worth the return cost.

Dvd was used, but in good condition. No skips or any problems with viewing a really excellent film...Much like the idea of "Lucy," another film about drug-enhanced limitless mind development, with some twists and turns in the plot to make this a very exciting and entertaining film. The acting was great, too. No complaints, except for the fact that it wasn't advertised as use, but it was in good condition.

Smart pills (nootropics), if such things are even possible, should have made Eddie Morra wiser and more cautious, but instead he did wild speculation on the stock market, and became involved in a risky business merger. Then he borrowed money from a known criminal! When Eddie heard that users of NZT were dying or getting very sick, he should have immediately sought professional medical help.
But he did not, which seems to imply that NZT was an extremely dangerous stimulant, not a true nootropic. After a year, the viewer is not sure whether Eddie has wisened up, or whether he is headed for even more dangerous adventures. The photography was jerky and poorly edited, and the dialogue was choppy. Viewer, please do not experiment with dangerous drugs!

It's such an interesting concept. All the actors play their role very well, and I'm sure everybody could use NZT at one time or another.

Limitless is a movie (and later a short lived TV series) based on the urban legend that people can only access a fraction of their brain's power/function/potential.  Bradley Cooper plays the typical movie version of a down on his luck guy named Eddie Morra, who is dead broke, wears ratty clothes etc.  He is a writer trying to finish a book and he comes across a drug called NZT, which allows a person taking it to access 100% of their brain's ability, turning them into an instant genius.

Through a series of events that I will not detail so as not to spoil it, Eddie becomes a highly successful financial wizard, but the side effects of the drug, getting in bad with a loan shark, and the perils of the big money financial world all end up getting in his way.  The story is not what I would call overly complex and does take a bit of suspension of disbelief to accept, but it is entertaining enough that it is easy to enjoy.  The acting is also very good with Cooper having to play a range of life situations for Eddie, and hold his own against Robert DeNiro.

For those who get the blu-ray, the movie looks and sounds great.  For extras there are a couple short making of and behind the scenes features.  An extended edition of the movie that really just adds a total of a couple minutes to the theatrical version run time, but does not change the story, a commentary track by the director, and an alternate ending.  The alternate ending actually leads much better into the TV series than the original ending that both the theatrical and extended edition show.  All in all, good for what is there.

Like I said it is not a complex story.  It is good to watch for any fan of the show, because while it is not necessary to get what is going on in the show, it is nice to see the backstory of the character of Eddie, who only makes brief almost cameo appearances in the television series.  It is a good way to spend an hour and  a half or so if you are looking for something different to watch.

Limitless (Unrated Extended Cut + Digital Copy) [Blu-ray]I am only giving this product 2 stars because of the blu ray disc which is very nice. However, with respect to the digital copy, I was very disappointed. The digital copy comes up on a separate disc, no code, (first time I see this), The instructions on how to redeem your digital copy are to insert the digital copy disc on your PC and just follow the instructions prompted from there. I did insert the disc and nothing happened, EXCEPT that my antivirus detected a TROJAN VIRUS in the disc and prompted me to eject the disc immediately . Like I said, I was very disappointed with this purchase because I could not get my digital copy for which I would have preferred just a redeem code to get my digital copy on VUDU or iTunes, like I have got on other purchases, instead of a disc with a Trojan virus inside.

The acting saved this movie. Bradley Cooper came off like a New York native and kept the pace up until the bitter end. De Niro, although master of his craft, was restrained by a smaller, less dimensional part. Being a De Niro fan, I would've loved to see more from him in a more dynamic role.

The movie itself is another drug movie, with a formulaic drug movie plot: Loser finds drugs, drugs are good, drugs get an awesome life, something bad happens (cops are on the trail, bad guys are trying to get money/drugs or both, guy tries to figure a way out), then main character either dies or manages to get out of the game.

I did enjoy the brief insider looks into philosophical premises though. Human being really only do use a small port of our brain and mind and this movie does attempt to answer, "what if we used all of our brain?"

I've known people in grad school who got their hands on adderall and modafinil and had the same ride this guy did. Other than Cooper and De Niro in a film together, I don't see what the fanfare was about.

We started watching the television program "Limitless" only to discover --when we were 4 episodes into the storyline-- that it was preceded by a film featuring the same crucial character: Bradley Cooper as Eddie Morra. So we decided to watch the 2011 film.

Limitless is suspenseful and everything that you could want in a science-fiction-style film focused on financial and political "conspiracies". Bradley Cooper is completely charming and invites us to care about his immediate future and ultimate survival. It has enough twists and turns to keep you interested and potentially surprised!

The only reason that I/we thought of rating the film at a 4 rather than a 5 is that the ending of the film leaves you unprepared for the person that Eddie Mora is the the continuing story of Limitless-- the tv show. Granted, that may be a fault of the current writers of the series rather than the previous writers of the film. Both productions have Neil Burger in common (developer of the film and one of the executive producers of the tv series), and yet the Eddie Mora of 2015 has changed in ways that the 4-year gap on storylines does not account for as a single fact. I find it a bit difficult to believe that Eddie Mora as depicted in 2011 would become Eddie Mora as depicted in 2015-- but perhaps we have not watched enough episodes of the tv series to understand the changes in character.

Regardless -- it is not reasonable to judge a film character and storyline by a later iteration of a character as part of a continuing storyline -- so the film gets its 5 stars! However -- DO watch the film before the television series. It is possible that the character evolution that I did not perceive will be blindingly obvious to you. Both projects are well done and peopled with excellent characters. Enjoy!

I recently reordered this movie after not watching it for a long time.  I was telling me teen son about it after watching SelfLess (Ryan Reynolds) as certain plot points had similarities and I was reminded how much I loved this flick.  Limitless is a very cool movie with Bradley Cooper as the main protagonist.  In it, he portrays a writer suffering from writer's block, and who is being dumped by his long-term girlfriend (Cornish) after she basically tells him he's a broke bum who isn't going anywhere in life.  After a chance meeting with his ex brother-in-law, he comes to learn of a new pharmaceutical drug known for "performance enhancement," and decides to try it out.  It works, oh boy does it work!  And the drug makes him "limitless."

Cooper's mind begins rapidly expanding, and it is then he meets DeNiro's character; a big-wig, money thumper.  The dialogue between these two becomes rather funny towards the end.  I can't say much about the inbetween without giving too much away.

This is a very interesting concept, especially as it teeters on the borderline of inappropriate drug use vs appropriate drug use and benefit vs detriment; but also it's really fun to see how amazing the brain opens up when Cooper is using.

Wouldn't we all love to function at our highest capacity?

I saw the theatrical release on DVD. It was...okay. As many have said, the visuals were very good, and I thought that Bradley Cooper and Abbie Cornish (she played Cooper's girlfriend) were very good. In particular, I thought Cooper did a great job of getting across the character's dichotomous mental states, though I had a hard time empathizing with him. DeNiro and the Russian mobster weren't awful, but they were very cookie-cutter.

I actually didn't have a problem with Cooper being as selfish as he was. That can be just as interesting and compelling as a more moral character. But here, that selfishness is just bland. There's nothing terribly interesting about it. Another thing that made it difficult for me to get behind his character was that the suspense, which largely pivoted around whether or not he'd get more pills in time to stave off a crash, wasn't that convincing. I wasn't worried enough for him to worry about what'd happen to him if he crashed. The movie never made me doubt enough that he'd be able to get his fix. I'm honestly not sure what it was, but I just couldn't get behind his character enough to really become invested in what happened to him. Maybe it was because, even though we're told and shown many things about his ups and downs in the beginning of the movie as he's trying out the pills, I never felt any of it. It didn't make that kind of connection with me. His meteoric rise just felt so stakes-less. He's on top of the world, but the movie never got me to care about that. In contrast, even though I wasn't very invested in her character either, that one suspenseful sequence with Cornish had me genuinely worried about what would happen to her.

I also didn't have a problem with the movie being based off of the "10% of the brain" myth. This is fiction. It's a bit of a silly idea, but if people want to have fun with it I'm more than happy to see where they take it.

I think my favorite thing about the movie is actually something it didn't do, which is where the comparison to 'Lucy' comes into play. People are not robots. Our defining trait is not logic (proof: computers have logic in spades, and are infinitely more capable at it than humans are). "Objectivity" isn't the pinnacle of humanity. It really aggravated me when, in Lucy, as Johansson's character became more intelligent and accessed more of her brain, she became more robotic and expressed less emotion. You want to know what happens when people really start functioning based solely on logic and reasoning? We can't make decisions. We take EVERYTHING into account. We consider every last bit of unimportant minutiae. There have been studies in the field of psychology that demonstrate this very clearly. It turns out that our "reasoning" is based in emotion. Digression aside, I really liked that 'Limitless' made it all about what the characters, and Cooper's character specifically, wanted subjectively. The problem was that it didn't get me to care about what he wanted.

The cinematic "suspend reality" is really reinforced in the opening sequence. It foreshadows the coming thrill ride.  The "Limitless" is an amplification of who you are...a zen, in that the amplifier is only as good as what is amplified.  No spoilers for this movie thats been out for years and the new TV Series, except that I respect what Bradley Cooper is trying to do...exaggerate what success as a metaphor is in life.  The director chose a thrill ride. It could have been an introspective movie as well.

"Limitless" thrills with excess, like many movies do (Wall Street-Gatsby-Ironman) indulging in teenage fantasies of irresponsibility, fast cars, fast women and being irresistible.  Until  a moment of consciousness and desperation, our hero indulges in the one drug, "success and power" with all the while managing to barely escape a sequence of near death situations.

A one star review synopsized it this way: "Five-word synopsis: Drug brings man material success."  But wait.  Robert DeNiro's character (sounding like a Boomer talking to a Millennial), warns that fast success comes without the depth of earning it. Its said in a threatening way, yet enemies are often the best teachers. Then the plot point happens as the love of the right woman causes a moment of clarity and mindfulness. That's the hidden beauty of this gem.  Anyone can evolve. Maybe there is hope.  Watch it and think not of Bradely Cooper as the actor, think of him as the Producer...

Aimless writer takes magic pill, brain fires up completely and life is set, well... until you forget to pay your Russian loan shark.

I like this movie- watched it several times. It's an escapist fantasy, no doubt: swallow a truly magic pill and problems are solved with sheer previously untapped brain power. And what does our character seek with all that power? Money, sex, more power. It's a fun little ride to watch, though there are a few things to ignore less they completely spoil the ride or even ruin the movie experience.

For example, he forgets to pay his loan shark. Of course, as an author you need some kind of device to keep the action moving but 'forgetfulness' after you've established that the protagonist doesn't only 'not forget' anything, he can remember the most obscure details that seemed barely glanced in passing. The loan shark is perfectly brutal and believable. As long as you tell yourself, 'even someone with a four digit IQ can forget the details in a haze of it all', you'll be alright.

Second, he's smart but he doesn't sound like it. His language is not too far removed from a common street hustler and sometimes it's really difficult to get past. Intelligent people use the right words with efficiency and economy- but I don't have a four digit IQ (whatever that means) so I have to accept that 'bling' and other less descriptive words just haven't reached my puny brain.

Third, his career choice: politics. I'm a relatively liberal person but I have a hard time seeing politics as the best way to solve the world's problems, if that's where the protagonist was heading (again, it could be part of his larger plan my brain could never understand). We'll assume he's wealthy, we know he's smart, but at the end of the day anyone can tell you those with absurd wealth (e.g. Gates, Musk, Walton, etc.) have the power to make the large changes in the world- not the president. It was a let down.

Fourth, his mockery of art. He learns foreign languages in no time, piano in four days, etc. I'm guessing because those are the 'soft' mental areas. In all honesty, it's strange to claim one might 'learn piano' in four days, because it's a creative endeavor and creation/expression never really stops. The same goes with foreign languages- one might gain some fluency but economic and beautiful expression... truly subjective and far from measurable. Somehow I don't think a Berlitz course, no matter how advanced, will make you the Goethe of Deutch or the Mark Twain of English- know what I mean?

Fifth, I didn't like the female lead (not that she led much, women were kind of tokenized in this). Perhaps it was her blonde hair. I mean, I'm happy the two ended up back together, but still, she just didn't appeal to me. Hey Hollywood- why don't you screen actresses past me first so that I can always be happy with the actors and actresses?

Heheheheh.

OK, onto the good stuff.

I was happy he outsmarted DeNiro's character. DeNiro plays a self-absorbed 'power-broker' (literally and figuratively) well and it's nice to see his comeuppance in the form of Bradley Cooper tenderly diagnosing his heart problem the way Spock tenderly knocks people out with the Vulcan death grip.

I was happy the other NZT guy's bodygaurd didn't kill Cooper's character- especially after his girlfriend slashed his face with an ice skating shoe. I guess he figured a big scar shows character and all's forgiven or something or other.

I liked that Cooper slept with his landlord's wife. She was really uptight about law school and needed to sleep it off.

I liked the way Cooper handled those thugs in the NY Subway- like when he grabbed into that guy's mouth; I've never thought of that. I mean, I don't get into subway fights all the time, nor do I watch martial arts shows so it probably wouldn't have come to me, but really, thumbs in the mouth... that had to terrify that big guy- Cooper deserved to win it.

I liked that he dove off a cliff without killing himself. It happened early on so that would have made a very short movie.

I liked that he drove someone else's Maserati around the island like a maniac. That's what they get for letting someone else drive their Maserati and that's what the island gets for letting Maserati's on it rather than forcing everyone to take a taxi or walk. Seriously, he's practically terrorizing that island. The guy who owns that car and the fancy house is totally going to an island prison cell. I'm guessing the car belongs to a dad who's really rich and his son is crazy spoiled so the son's always getting him in trouble like that, but this time the son's probably going to get in very hot water. There's a separate movie/spinoff waiting to happen (just send the actresses to me first for pre-screening so we don't end up with that blonde).

I liked Bradley Cooper's suit(s).

I liked that the brother in law got shot in the head. He wasn't doing anyone any good, though he did give Cooper the pill for free so perhaps there was hope but I didn't have the patience to find out.

I liked that the Russian loan shark discovered Google. If he had lived, it could have really helped him find stuff.

I liked that Cooper didn't go to jail (again) for the Russian guy's killing the neighbors, shooting up the place and leaving a bloody mess. I mean, was it really his fault?

I liked that Cooper finished the book fast (a lot of weight off his shoulder right there).

I liked that he was able to make the Chinese waiter laugh. Shows he has a versatile sense of humor in different languages.

That's about it.

I really enjoyed this movie...of course, Bradley Cooper made it wonderful.

I wanted more from this movie.  The premise is intriguing if well trodden, "what if you had access to 100% of your brain".
And at first it is fun imagining what it would be like to be a great day trader, the standard "lottery winner" fantasies, but that gets old very fast.  Instead of exploring what you could do with that intelligence, the movie devolves into drug-deals-gone-bad, drug induced black outs, being smart gets you lots of sex, and my favorite: the magic "writers block" fix.

This appears as if it was written by a recovering drug addict hoping that all ills could be cured with another drug.  A Scarface who wins?

The visuals, if overdone, were woven into the story well. The colors are all brighter when Bradley Cooper is on the drug than when he is off.  The viewer feels disoriented when Bradley is, and sharper when he is, too.

Ultimately what doesn't work for me is that if he is so smart why is he constantly doing stupid things?

SPOILERS

First off, he has $800 he turns into $4000 in one day.  He says "this isn't going fast enough, I need money but no one loans money to a guy like me".
So, duh, off to the loan shark, who is known for _flaying_ his clients, for a $100,000 loan!
Loan shark says "why should I loan you the money?"  Bradley says "because I can increase my money 4x every day".
Hmm, let me see.  $4000 x 4 x 4 x 4 is $128,000.  He can't wait 3 days to avoid being flayed at the end of the movie?
Then, Mr millionaire *forgets to pay back the loan shark*.  sigh.

This is a central plot point throughout the movie, too.  Take more pills Bradley!

Second, his girlfriend in order to escape bad guy uses the drug to calculate that she can grab a little girl on ice skates, swing her around, and cut the bad guys face.
Good job ruining that kids life.

Third, oh why bother.  In the end we cut to a "12 months later" and everything is tied up.

So many dropped story lines.
* What happened to his girlfriend (who at least wised up that he was a drug addict and dumped him).
* What happened to the woman he murdered (or was framed, we don't know it was just dropped).
* What happened to his ex-wife who turned into a meth-head after taking the drug.  Did he cure her?

I think we're supposed to like Bradley, but in the end he just acts like Scarface throughout, so... yay he's a Senator at the end?

Anyway.  It's decent fantasy for an hour and a half, but ultimately unsatisfying.

I'd give it 4 and half, if that was possible. This is the movie that launched the series currently showing on TV (at the time of this post). I believe, that while the series may not last, the movie will. As science fiction piece, it plays upon a believable premise of chemical/medicinal advances that are a mix of conceivable and the rhetoric of the modern day snake oils promising physical stature, weight loss, enhanced sexual ability and, of course, accessing the unused potential of our minds.

Writers, stock investors, financiers and pharmaceutic personnel may enjoy this, especially. Not to mention that its fast pace, corporate conspiracy and drug addiction topics bring this close to home for many, today.

This new series on television will be one of the big hits of the 2015/2016 season.  Interesting and novel premise and although Bradley Cooper was the main star in this two-hour movie, the hour-long television series has him in a supporting role and another actor performing the action feats (at least in the first show of the season.)  This series will be for people who enjoy "Person of Interest", "Nikita" starring Pita Wilson, and other action shows such as "24".  I originally bought this DVD because Bradley Cooper starred in it and I was not disappointed--it's a great new series on television and IMO will run for multiple seasons as long as the writing continues to be as good as it is starting out.

If you enjoyed the film Lucy, then you will enjoy Limitless.
They are of a similar concept but quite different, this isn't just a male version of Lucy.
Quick plot summary, author with writers block, meets ex-brother in law who persuades him to take newly developed drug for brain power enhancement. The effects potentially limitless.
Finishes book, works the stock market making lots of money. Offered job by financial legend (Robert De Niro) and chased by Russian mafia and other faceless foes.
Acting is very good and the effects his enhanced character and effects of the drug wearing off are very well portrayed.
There is a wonderful twist of an ending that was very satisfying,

Whenever I rate a movie, I'm not sure if I'm supposed to rate the movie itself, or just the packaging and physical media itself.  Since, you can go to any movie review site and read any of hundreds of reviews you want anyway.
But I'm going to rate the movie itself this time, because I was let down.  The gimmicky camera-work of walking into the scene faster and faster and faster got old fast.  It actually gave my wife a headache.  And as much as I like Bradley Cooper, there was nothing here that clicked for me and made me feel anything for his situation.  The video quality and audio themselves were great.  But the movie itself was a let-down.
Is this pure opinion?  Of course.  But I think the movie dragged in places it shouldn't, and then sped up at points where more character development could have happened.  Simply not a movie I plan on watching again.

A brilliant adaptation of Alan Gln's novel 'Dark Fields'. Bradley Cooper has just the right combination of the 'Everyman' morphing into pure intellectual power with the help of a mysterious designer drug. Abby Cornish and Robert DeNiro provide superb performances; with Mr DeNero in particular providing an understated, yet compelling role as a business tycoon.  Cooper's transformation from a slacker copywriter into super investment analyst show the full range of his actor's range, while demonstrating the vulnerabilities and missteps of Eddie Spinaola a "regular guy", reeling from the intense pressure of his transformation.

While the screenplay deviates from the novel, it retains much of the intense pace and hyper realism of the original.  Do not miss this one!

This is a review of the digital copy redemption, not for the actual movie. For some stupid reason, this comes with a "Digital Copy" that ONLY works on iTunes or Windows Media Player. There is no support for redemption on any online service such as Google Play, or the industry standard, Ultraviolet. Fox claims this is because it's an "older title" which is hooey. As I don't have a physical drive, this is pretty much useless.

This is an awesome show.  It is about a guy who unlocks all the potential of his brain at once, thereby allowing him to make connections that are not obvious to the common person.  He then uses this initially for short term gains until he realizes the potential he has with it and goes for it big time.  Another excellent Bradley Cooper show that is a must for every collection.  Plus this has the unrated extended version and theatrical version along with a digital copy of the theatrical version.  I love this show.

An increasing theme in TV shows these days is the "smart thinking outside the box" detective, public servant, or whoever... who blows away audiences with their powers of observation, deduction and abductive reasoning.  It seems that to enjoy this movie, you absolutely must have missed out on the last decade of interesting shows that use this premise.

The reason is that Bradley Cooper's character is really not very smart at all.  Then simultaneously he is doing impossible things (I won't name them here, no spoilers in this review).  This mashup between incredibly dumb decisions and impossible superhero achievements makes the movie altogether unenjoyable.  It doesn't help that the idea of the human brain being mostly untapped was scientifically discredited decades ago.

The main plot of this movie hangs on the premise that he borrowed money, proceeded to make 500% gains per day, but either couldn't remember to pay off his loan or couldn't figure out how to liquidate some of his positions to pay off the loan...  exactly why he couldn't achieve this simple task is never explained.

The icing on the cake is that Bradley Cooper's character is a real "jerk" (a stronger adjective would be more appropriate).  His character is not likable... for example, he's constantly and thoroughly selfish from the beginning to the end of this movie. No lessons learned, other than that finding shortcuts in life are fun and let you take selfishness to a whole new level. Yay.

"Limitless" has all the compelling drama and immersive storyline of any of the recent big budget scifi blockbusters, and does it with about a thousandth of the special effects. The effect of the tech on human lives is at the core of all the best scifi, and this movie minimizes the scifi and maximizes the story of Morra's (Bradley Cooper) awakening. There have been a few movies made about the double-edged sword that high IQ can be (Little Man Tate, A Beautiful Mind, Charly, and even Back ToThe Future) and ' Limitless' seems to borrow from them all. Morra can see patterns in data on a computer monitor that his mind is adding to it, and sometimes the data he's juggling in his head seems to be projected on the walls of the room he's in. Similar to the plot of 'Charly', the increased intelligence can go away, also, but in this film, when Morra slides back to his mundane (but reasonably intelligent yet self-sabotaging} mind, it is portrayed as leaving him in situations he embarrassingly no longer understands, rather than a heartrending return to relative darkness. After all, he could get back in the cockpit thirty seconds after taking another pill, and that's just the inefficient, slow digestive method, as he comes to find out.
DeNiro plays a very bright and deeply savvy Wall St entrepeneur, and plays it convincingly. I've been slowly getting over my automatic expectation that, whenever he smiles, he's about to personally blow someone's kneecaps off, but in this film he uses his skills to instill fear as only a hardened, crooked multi-millionaire can. De Niro danger is there, but he's also very cunning.
The film leaves a few questions open at the end, which would fit nicely with a sequel, but IMHO maybe the rest of this story should be left up to our imaginations. If a sequel got made, I wouldn't be able to stay away, though. Something about watching a regular guy learning to control his new "4 digit IQ" is very addictive, and we should all perhaps feel lucky that, like with Jim Carrey in ' The Mask ', it couldn't have happened to a nicer guy.

The movie did something that rarely happens in today's 21st Century film making:  it tells an extraordinarily gripping story of a young man's (Bradley Cooper's) rise to the top and does it without all the hyperbole of outrageously, over done "green screen" movie making!  In other words, it tells that story and does so straightforwardly, from A to Z.  It uses that same movie making formula which back in the 20th Century led to American cinema being considered far and away the best in the world!  I hope it serves now to open the eyes of all these so called "Hollywood movie makers".  Just  bring us stories, well written, well directed stories that give actors roles that they can bring to life.  The actors of today are starving for such roles and the movie goers are starving to see them!
Note:  The emphasis should be on storytelling, not on explosions!

Overall, I really enjoyed the movie; plenty of suspense, action, and a pretty good plot.  However, I felt that the writer/author/whatever didn't seem to comprehend the character they had created.  This guy was a genius, yet made stupid mistake after stupid mistake.  *SPOILER* Who doesn't check that their 'stash' of magic drug isn't where they left it?  Who puts all their eggs in one basket?  This genius made so many mistakes, mistakes I, a dithering moron, was able to figure out before he made them.

Limitless
 This uneven film starts from a very promising premise.  What would happen to a person if he suddenly became able to use every twisty corner of his brain instead of just the parts we can get to on a day to day basis?  What if every single thing we have ever seen, heard, read or experienced became as accessible to us as what we had for breakfast?  And what would happen if we could read and organize information at a super rapid rate?  Well, we should be able to do well in the field of high finance, dating and very importantly, avoiding bad guys who want to take advantage of our new talent.
 Bradley Cooper plays a failing writer who is given a new drug which accelerates his mental acuity to a fantastic degree.  In the course of the film he becomes wealthy and successful with women.  He manages to defeat his several opponents, commit murder most foul and eventually to become a well adjusted, super smart, nice guy.  It is an entertaining ride and Cooper does the role the justice that it deserves.  The spectacularly beautiful Abbie Cornish plays his on again/off again girlfriend in a decidedly supporting role.
 Director Neil Burger turns out to have a dab hand with the camera.  The best parts of the movie are really made possible because of his directorial skill, rather than by the fine acting jobs done by his cast.  The cast includes movie icon Robert De Niro in a terrific role as the financier that we love to hate.  This is his most interesting role in years and De Niro takes advantage of the opportunity to play to his strengths.
 If I was to order a re-write of the script, I would have left out the part where the hero, in a frenzy induced by the designer smart drug, kills a young socialite.  He is so smart that he escapes his justice, but after that it makes it hard to root for the guy when everything closes in on him.
 In the 1995 film Phenomenon John Travolta plays another ordinary guy who suddenly becomes super smart.  In his film, he becomes wise as well as smart.  I find the earlier film to be much the more satisfying.  The protagonist in Limitless becomes wise by the end of the film, but it is too late for me to care.  The dead socialite spoils the wine.
 This well directed, finely acted PG-13 (drug use, lots of violence) film made $19 million in its opening weekend, a good way to making back the seemingly small $27 million budget.  I would like to award this entertaining action/thriller more than an average three saw blades, but I just cant.  It runs a bit low at one hour and 45 minutes.  Clipping out the dead socialite bit would have only taken another two or three minutes.

[Rounded up from 3-1/2 Stars, Spoiler Alert] Bradley Cooper plays "Eddie Morra," a writer with major writer's block and little going for him, whose life goes into overdrive (in questionably positive ways) after taking a mystery pill given to him by his ex-brother-in-law (and drug dealer), who says it taps into every nook and cranny of your brain's potential (he said more than the usual 20%, but I, seriously, always thought it was 2%).  But someone "takes care of" his ex-brother-in-law, making Eddie believe this is the most powerful drug on the synthetic market.  Soon, Eddie starts running low and the side effects kick in, with previous users dying or already dead, except his ex-wife, who says it's possible to wean off the synthetic drug if done vigilantly.  But then Eddie seems to think that he's found the right balance to take it indefinitely, which is especially tempting since his work colleague/supervisor (Robert DeNiro) says that he can just whip it up in a lab, now having the resources.  Can Eddie resist, or will he take the high road?  Entertaining and well done all around (and, I'd say, a favorite, as a drug endorsement, of profit-seeking pharmaceutical companies and over-prescribing healthcare providers), but what values are being taught here? Say yes to drugs because Hollywood pretty-boy Cooper is scarfing them down in a cool movie? Synthetic drugs (and street drugs) will solve all your problems because you have no other choice, and you can safely rely on them?  Per Nancy Reagan, just say no to (street) drugs.

Interesting movie which could have been so much better had it not chosen to use action movie mode to tell the story. This movie could have really contributed much to the investigation of what is the nature of intelligence. You will notice in the movie, and I recommend it as it is a good movie, that the basic premise of the ability gained by the protagonist was the ability to first observe, evaluate information and estimate the situation to arrive at the correct action to resolve the situation. That is the primary sequence used throughout the movie. And it is a true sequence. This could have led to a different story rather than one of fleeing from gangsters and conflict with another man (Robert DeNiro) which ended in a petty one-upmanship with the protagonist, Cooper, winning. However, the movie is intriguing and has moments of on the edge of your seat expectancy. I recommend it.

SIX STARS from me. For clarity, all those one star reviews are mostly from people that just can't comprehend that the review portion of Amazon is to actually review the movie, not to rant about delivery problems or non working discs. So overall, there is a strong agreement that "Limitless" is a solid film.

If you don't know the premise ( but I think you do ), I'm sorry, I won't be writing about it but will be sticking to highlighting the amazing plot. "Limitless" uses every formula that has ever worked in films to the hilt and encapsulates them into one intelligent film. Bradley Cooper nails every scene as he shows us how what we mentally desire is as initially rewarding as we thought. He displays all the facial ticks necessary to reveal the switch from cerebrally dull to super sharp. I think the story taps into the walking doldrums that many people have. Lying dormant in a good number of us is that book or screenplay screaming to get out. We see in the film what could play out if (as Coppers character Eddie Morra says) we could remove all of the shyness and awkwardness that can be part of being human. In doing so , the film accurately depicts the desperate desires anyone with such proclivities would do to attain a drug to fix it all immediately. All the little things we've picked up in life from PBS shows to Kung Fu movies being utalized to the extreme is ultra fascinating. And that's what this movie is, the incredibly fascinating journey of a man.

This is also Deniro's best role in quite awhile. He envelops the "seeing through it all" persona to the point that it makes even the super smart Eddie Morra nervous. It takes time for Morra to inhabit his drug fueled life to the point where he can deal with Deniro equally . A very real scenario with a fictional drug. Morra's "hangovers" are deliciously played as they invoke such desperate feelings of what was had and lost that it is universally relatable.

The sensual Abbie Cornish plays Morra's girlfriend  Lindy and is believable as she questions the drug. Her experience imbibing it made total sense under duress . As an action film, "Limitless" never disappoints with cutting edge stunts. You really get a totally exciting cinematic experience with this film. A portion of the ending could have been stronger but if you mentally use ambiguity to compensate, it can be overlooked because the film is otherwise very strong.

Definitely one of my new top ten films.

I have to admit that the inspiration I just wrote was the last thing I would expect to happen when I  purchased this limitless (starring Bradley cooper) dvd at my walmart job for just five dollars back around September 2014. After all, my husband and I enjoyed watching limitless together when we saw it in movie theaters in 2011 and were both drawn to the idea of the possibilities that could be unleashed if a person can increase their intelligence/genius by just taking a pill. I was mainly looking to explore that possibility again when I purchased this limitless dvd,but something just clicked in me in the scene when he accomplishes the feat of writing his novel. There have also been a series of positive incidences that have also gave me a reminder on how seeking out wisdom and  striving for the greatness of genius have been discussed; a natalie portman articIe online where she acknowledged the importance of intellectual growth (I intend to update this review later with one of the articles because Im aware she is widely known for both her brains and beauty), coming across a book at my job where a woman realized that her beauty can only carry her so far and that her greater focus must be on wisdom,  a local news article discussing benedict cumberbatchs role in the imitation game, and a yahoo news connection on chris hemsworth starring in an upcoming movie based on someone known for their genius). However, I wish to avoid saying more on it and to just at least acknowledge that this movie limitless and the actors (Bradley cooper)portrayal inspired me to pursue a side writing career ( a new years resolution).  Bradley cooper stars as the character of eddie morra, whose life turns 180 degree turn for the better when he is given a pill that expands his potential. Morra ends up attacting  the wealth and love that he craves. However, he meets gets his life turned upside down by another powerful and wealth man named Carl Van loon (Robert DeNiro) who would like to exploit his abilities at morras expense.  The following dvd extras are attributed to limitless; immortals, the warriors way, season of the witch, x-men first class.

This film is the 'Benjamin Buttons' of drug addition. Effectively, it attempts to turn drug addiction inside out by postulating a new 'designer drug' that not only increases your brainpower, but can actually help you get ahead in the world... unlike real drugs like Meth or Cocaine that rot you tend to rob the user's life and money. Thus, this initially makes you think this might actually be an uplifting tale. While this idea of taking a pill that unlocks your brain potential seems like a really cool premise, the writers couldn't avoid taking it to the inevitable place as a banal cautionary tale of drug addiction. I mean, why bother with that social commentary at all? It's easy to flip on Amazon instant video and pull up many documentaries about drug addiction, why spend the money on entertainment only to get this same message shoved into your face?

No, the writers should have steered clear of this commentary in Limitless. While it would have been okay for Bradley's character to find out what happens if you quit the drug cold turkey, it would have been simple enough to make sure he had plenty on hand so that didn't happen. In fact, after learning of his newfound brain skills, his first task would have been to reverse engineer the drug so he could make more and have an infinite supply right from the go. Instead, the movie fails as he focuses on mergers and acquisitions, becoming a drug dealer and dealing with people who get upset when they don't get their next fix. This is not a particularly brilliant plot point. Knowing he had a limited supply of these pills and no source to get more, he would have certainly explored having more made as the first thing he does, not something he does 3/4 of the way through the film's plot. Unfortunately, by this point in the film, it's more than apparent that the story has degraded into a cheesy tale of drug addiction on Wall Street.

This is a review of the Digital copy, not the movie. We always get the digital copy pack whenever possible, it is just easier than having our disks get scattered about the house if kids want to watch a movie or worse get lost because somebody borrows one. It is always an easy process, open the packaging get the code, go online and add it to our library on Amazon, Vudu, Disney ...... whichever service.
 NOT WITH THIS MOVIE,  THE "DIGITAL COPY " is a separate disk which needs to be loaded into a computer ( isn't a physical disk a contradiction of "digital copy" to begin with ) then you are supposed to enter your code to transfer it to your HDD in Itunes or WMV format. ( Hello, if I wanted to just rip the disk onto my HDD, I would not need to bother paying extra to get the disk and digital copy)
 So first I try the WM option and first get a pop up saying I need to install some sync app, but when I click the link it opens a window to buy a windows phone. Yes I am insane, because I clicked the box at least 3-4 times somehow expecting a different result. So then I just close that popup and click transfer, this time I get a popup telling me I need to upgrade windows media security protocol ,okay I click and windows update opens ,scans then tells me I have the latest version and no further updates are available. Okay lets try this again and once again I somehow expected a different result ,yet got the same results from the same actions. Clicking the " help" link brings you to the Fox online store so you can buy another copy. I am not sure why if I already own a copy the Help to watch it is to buy another copy.
Okay I give up on Windows media and decide to go with the Itunes option. So I exit back to the disk main menu and click Itunes ( Yes we have an Itunes account even though we never use the service, I am reminded daily when it pops up telling me it needs to be updated, I think it is the only software that needs to be updated more than Adobe ) So Itunes opens and logs in and starts syncing all the new music etc on the computer . It gets done syncing and I click the disk menu and surprise surprise " error please try again later" , so once again just to prove I am insane I try this 3-4 times as well consistently expecting a different result.
At this point it has been almost an hour wasted trying to access this digital copy and I realize I could have already watch the movie and been onto the bonus material.
Amazon needs to get their licensing straightened out, so when I buy a movie with digital copy it is automatically added to my Amazon library and no more of this BS free 2 day rental while you wait for the disk to arrive, especially when the digital copy included with the disk is useless.

While I know this is not a great movie, I really like it. As a working writer, I can identify with Bradley Cooper's character, Eddie, the struggling novelist on the brink of total failure. Who of us has not wished for a magic pill like this while wrestling with "creative issues?" Watching the ramifications of his new-found brilliance play out is kind of like wish fulfillment -- great fun, even if the plot specifics are a little muddy from time to time. The off-kilter camera work matches the giddy, heightened-reality feeling when Eddie is under the influence, helping to push it all along at near-warp speed so we don't have time to think about it. Robert DeNiro may have been miscast as the billionaire tycoon mentor/potential nemesis, but he finds a way to make it work. Abby Cornish is great as Eddie's girlfriend. This could have been a thankless role, but she plays it smart and strong. The Russian mobsters are a bit of a clich, but so what. They're perfect for a quasi-fantasy like this one. All in all, good, entertaining fun.

Essentially, this writer with what appears to be issues with self-esteem, lack of will power, difficulty concentrating, cleanliness; is going downhill rapidly. He owes money to everyone. He can't get a chapter written much less the book. His girlfriend tells him she is no longer to be his paycheck, house-cleaner, cook... and leaves.

He is lower than a snake's belly in a wagon rut, when he runs into his ex-brother-in-law, a former drug dealer, who says he has cleaned up his act and now sells pharmaceuticals for a company, and is doing very well.  He, sees what a mess our hero is in and offers him ONE pill of a new drug, which he says will make him feel and think better than he has ever done in his life. This pill normally costs $800 a pop, and has not yet been released, though FDA approved. (Don't know why the hero thought FDA approval made it safe....) The ex-brother-in-law gets a call and has to run off, right as our hero is saying he doesn't want the pill, which is left behind with him anyway.

Well on the way home, hero...who is depressed, thinks what the hey and takes the miracle drug.  The guy goes into overdrive, cleaning up his apartment and writing that first chapter that will get him his advance from his literary agent.  He goes to the agent, and is still hyper and tells her, with her EXTREMELY doubtful...because she has been dealing with this jerk for a while, that after she has read a few paragraphs IF she doesn't want the piece, he will bring back her advance; to call him later that night.

He goes home and has three messages. The first is from the agent, she says she has read a few pages and she likes them, but does not yet know if he is going to be able to sustain his style through the whole piece. The next message from her also...she has read a few more pages, and she is excited and thinks he has a good concept and potentially valuable piece. The final message is from his heavy breathing, excited agent who is kissing up to him big time...and he knows he has her, the contract and the opportunity to make some good money to live on. He goes looking for his brother-in-law to get more pills.

He goes to the apartment where his brother-in-law lives...door is open...he goes in...apartment torn up...he sees his brother in law sitting on the sofa, back to him...he goes to see him and the guy's brains are blown out...and from there this fantasy becomes a thriller with a twist at the end.

The interest, the action, the compression of the film stays good right up till the end...AND a viable end IS obtained, BUT I gave it 4 stars because it needed a little more development at the end to have made the denouement work better. Still a very enjoyable thriller.

Decent Movie...could have been even better, but this is what can happen with adaptation.  It's fun to imagine our potential...the fun is in figuring out how to tap into it...and it certainly is not with drug abuse. Use is one thing abuse is another...Watch and see how the main character Cooper figures this out.  Once the neuro-connections are established...one truly reprogram.  It takes awareness, acceptance, willingness and an acute diligence to do the work to make things happen by creating a new awareness. With a new reprogrammed awareness your life becomes in incredible sequence of synchronicities, but you must pay attention so you can notice them.

Some people say that we're all addicted to one thing or another, it's just a bit more obvious in some people as to what they're addicted to.  Agree or disagree but it does seem to be true that most people strive after some thing or another, whether it's gasps of air and life or it's wealth or love or whatever.  How we go about obtaining what we seek, whether we earn it by our own hands and the sweat of our brow or it drops into our laps via being in the right place at the right time seems to us an importance.  Not so much to Eddie Morra (Bradley Cooper), the protagonist of the film "Limitless", a failed writer and generally down on his luck bunko who can't seem to get things straight, until a miracle drug that unlocks the potential of his mind to absorb information through his physical faculties and to predict incredibly accurately near-future events.  It is, of course, too good to be true and the effects fade and so we follow what is essentially a junkie looking for his next fix throughout a film that sees him trying to keep ahead of the trouble that he's created in front of him.  There are some snazzy action pieces in this sci-fi lite plot premise but the film is mostly a character study, somewhat cerebral, and goes to lengths to baffle the audience at film's end as to whether or not Morra has conquered (controlled really) his demon in the form of a pill, a hit.  To this end he faces off against partner/ antagonist Carl van Loon (Robert DeNiro) who may be more like Morra than Morra knows.

The film could have gone longer into the drug addicted persona of its star but it goes far enough and it offers itself as a thriller more than a sci-fi action movie.  It is definitely a visceral experience at points but the thing that troubles me are the messages of the film (it is a good discussion piece for a movie if you're into that sort of thing): the pursuit of power and potential by artificial means are justified by the ends; the fairy tale element of the addict overcoming (?) their addiction through pharmaceuticals; the mundanity of life made better through drugs.  I will say, at least, that the film does not minimize the effects of addiction completely which is important.  I would imagine that those who have suffered serious and debilitating drug addictions versus those who haven't might view this film differently.  3.75 stars.

An aspiring writer Eddie Morra/Bradley Cooper whose life is a mess, gets turned onto a new pill, NZT-48 by his ex-girlfriend's brother. The NZT allows Eddie o focus intently and reach his maximum potential. In days he's able to master the stock market, finish his novel and impress the hell out of his publisher and basically turn his life around....UNTIL he finds the dark side of NZT.

He finds himself pursued by a Russian mob loan shark, and an unscrupulous stock manipulator (Robert DeNiro) amidst the realization that all those who've previously taken NZT are dead or very ill. Fascinating storyline, memorable characters and a good flow to the story made this movie highly enjoyable to me.

Bradley Cooper plays Eddie Morra, hes an unpublished writer with writers block and is deteriorating into a bit of bum. He runs into his ex brother in law who gives him a drug that makes his iq skyrocket by having all the synapses fire and the ability to use more of his brain power. After he experiences it he goes back for more, but then the brother in law gets killed, he finds his stash, starts using it and becomes successful in business, genius writer, and great with the ladies. Then he starts experiencing side effects from the drug, realizes people are after him for his stash, and generally his whole world starts collapsing. By the end of the movie he weens himself off but still maintains some of the mental abilities. While the movie is unbelievable I enjoyed it because the scenes where he is on the drug is visceral and makes me live for a brief moment in that world. Ive done my share of drugs, and the idea of a new drug that can elevate my abilities, make me feel THAT good, and be THAT successful is basically the holy grail of what we all hope for when we do drugs. The ending is unbelievable because anyone whos done a modicum of illicit substances know that theirs no happy ending, especially since Eddie sees the effects on the drug on other people whos used it: death, premature aging, dementia. It doesnt make sense that he escapes those things when he was abusing it at a rate higher than the rest. They didn't give any explanation for why he does and being lucky isn't a good explanation. Anyway, its a movie, it allows me to suspend reality, and I enjoyed it.

First, I think it is confusing in the sense that it seems that this movie is basically an advertisement for a pill (i.e.  [...] - which featured Bradley Cooper, which apparently is no longer functioning - and a real clear pill available at webnutrients.com  - so it left me wondering what was real and what wasn't and how there could be a situation where you could take a drug this powerful without going through a doctor, etc..  Apparently there are drugs like this that you can take..  So, I'm wondering what is real and what isn't real...  This is sold as a work of fiction, but it might not be.

Also it is confusing in that they have the ending of the movie and the alternative ending (which they should not have included) -  as it made you wonder if they really knew what they were doing when they made the movie.

It has lots of action and it is enjoyable to watch. I really disliked this character greatly - and honestly since she dumped him, he should have forgotten about her.

The movie really does a good job showing the dangers of taking a pill like this - but it does say that if you are one of these people who just can't pull it together then maybe there's a medication which could be an answer for you.  I would be one of these kind of people.

I honestly thought the guy at the first part of the movie was much more likeable than the one at the end.

Dressing nice is good, not dressing nice isn't good, etc etc.  and you do whatever you need to do even if this drug hurts your body to get the money and the power and the women, even if you have people chasing you trying to kill you all the time - whatever the cost - it is worth it - when in truth it isn't worth it  I think the main character is a jerk. I love this movie, it really highlights the ups and downs of drug abuse to the ultimate of both ends.  With this new drug, you can literally do anything you can think or dream of, it opens and expands your mind and taps into that part of your brain that we supposedly never even use.  It's hard to see the downside of such a drug, at first.  Until our protagonist learns of long time users dying from addiction or even trying to stop.  When he tries to stop, he suffers first hand how sick he becomes and longs for another taste of the success the drug unleashes inside him.

Such an amazing film with great special effects, great actors, and great life lessons and realism on drugs.

(SPOILER ALERT) Alternate Ending
I was a bit disappointed, however, with the alternate ending this DVD version offered, it was anticlimactic in comparison to the original, which of course is why it was cut and they went with the original, but I just expected more, all the same.  I did enjoy the bit about finding a "cure" in the talk between Cooper and Pacino in that version, and wish they had worked that into the original ending, however I would have been happier had they actually worked that into the movie (the use of the drug's powers into his mind and him working into finding a cure to get off the drug) rather than just a conversation about such.

All the same, a brilliant movie about an amazing drug that wrecks lives in the end, Highly Recommended to watch!
