A premise of an "ultimate" drug that temporarily increases your cognitive skills literally exponentially (OK, so they use that stupid idea to explain the drug that we don't use 80% of our brains simply because we, uh, just can't--one of the dumbest myths ever spoken since people started believing Einstein failed math when he had understood it better than almost anyone by the time he was 10 years old--as the official explanation, but it's given by the dealer himself as the explanation, so he gets a pass for just selling it), given to a run-down, poor writer? A predictable, though satisfying, initial course of what happens when the drug wears off, and one needs more to sustain that? A hint that the drug's been around a very long time, and past events were influenced by this not-too-unbelievable "ultimate" drug?

Just like the drug, sounds too good to be true, but you can't deny that everything is set up for something astonishing to happen.

Yet, it doesn't. Around the beginning of the second-half, all character, interesting plot, sub-plots, and thematic developments comes to a near-complete stop. Common sense starts going out the window in a series of odd events in which the main character, and everyone around him, starts to behave in ways that aren't consistent with the events of the first half. They simply disappear from the screen, and by anti-climax, it's pretty much *all* gone except the trailer.

It's almost poetic in how this film crashes harder than the not-even-close-to-outside-reality drug and the world on which it's based. It's impossible not to stop at some point during the film and start questioning what every single character is doing, which becomes increasingly more evident as the film's pages seem to stick together in places. All the stuff implicated about his past life being influenced by the drug beforehand? Once it's implicated, it's dropped. The romantic sub-plot? Gone after a point without any real explanation, and is never mentioned again. Even Robert De Niro's role, which starts off promising, takes an almost comedic backseat to astonishingly-implausible situations that lack basic movie coherence.

By the time the credits roll, the whole film has changed from something genuinely interesting, provocative, and potentially deep, into a lighthearted, carefree, comedic, drug-infused fantasy that has successfully baited-and-switched what you thought you were going to get the whole time, which is, well, some sort of half-satisfying conclusion. Well, we get what's technically a conclusion, and it doesn't conclude all that much, then literally skips some (if not most) of the somewhat important plot points that you're led to believe are going to *be* the focal point of the climax.

Instead, in place of an actual logical conclusion to the plot and the characters it's built up all this time, we get, uh, this screen:

"Twelve months later..."

And that's literally what happens right when you think the story needs to wind down. When the main character deals with the problems he's caused along with the successes he's created. They outright skip the part you've been anticipating was inevitable: The drop, the consequences, and the kind-of-significant things the character has inadvertently done to others as a result of his dependence, and even his whole life from then on. They cut to a year later, explain it in about two sentences with an absurd outro, and the credits roll, leaving every single answer to every meaningful question anyone could possibly have completely off-screen, with as little exposition as possible in as tight a time as possible.

It's like all of a sudden, during the filming phase, a giant buzzer went off indicating they were out of time, the budget *just* hit zero, and everyone involved in making the film says they've got that thing to go to.

The "alternate ending" provided is only marginally more sensible, but not even close to what one would at least consider courteously wrapping some things up, even if it skips a few minor details that aren't worth it (it happens). It's not exactly the original "alternate" or "controversial" endings to "I Am Legend", "The Descent", or "Die Hard With A Vengeance", all of which made the title of the film make sense (i.e., the title held all the original meaning in its climax), so don't expect anything like that.

The title of the film apparently means something totally different when they coin it again at the end, but it's definitely not a meaning you'd expect (much less want) from a film that set up so much beforehand.

Her early draft of the script is available online and was a bit truer to the book in that Eddie didn't get to have a happy ending.
In this version, Eddie appears on track to gaining unlimited financial and political power, but at the price of his soul.

Don't be deceived by the "unrated extended cut" banner there are a few more minutes of character exposition than the original, most notably, Eddie Morra's meeting with his ex-wife all of which neither detracts or adds to the pacing and plot line.  There are no great side plots in this version that was edited from the theatrical.  For those expecting to see an alternate ending in the extended version, they may be disappointed to find it is the same as the theatrical.  The "Exclusive Alternate Ending"  . . . . . ......SPOILER ALERT . . . . . . . . is a separate bonus clip, which is oversold on the BLU-Ray packaging, leading one to believe the ending would have been mind blowingly different from the original, reshaping the entire context of the feature film . . . last chance for SPOILER ALERT . . . . . . . . well let's just say there is a minor variation from the theatrical ending, which I found far less satisfying than the original.

This is still a great deal especially if it is (at the time of this review) $5.99 for the Blu-ray.  Limitless is original and loaded with suspense and the theatrical version is also included.

As far as the movie is concerned I thought it was great!  We're big Bradley Cooper fans and this was an exciting drama that kept you guessing throughout the film.  Quick synopsis for you without giving away too much...  Bradly Cooper is a struggling writer with a lack of drive and focus who is floundering through life.  There is a new drug in development that he is introduced to by way of his ex-brother-in-law which unlocks the other 90% of the brain which is not used.  With this increased awareness the user can live without limits as they become hyper aware and able to access all information that they have previously been exposed to.  Unfortunately, there are some terrible and debilitating side-effects and no shortage of people who would kill to get their hands on this drug for themselves.

As this is presently under $10 (think I picked it up on super sale for $4), I think it's worth adding to your movie collection.  As someone who is working to move my movies into the cloud, I also picked this version up because it comes with a DigitalCopy code.  While I generally like both iTunes (we have AppleTV's) and UltraViolet (works via our BluRay streaming) codes, for whatever reason the Limitless code is what I can only describe as a handicapped digital version.

The reason being you redeem it via iTunes, but the code does NOT entitle you to download or stream the movie through iTunes.  There is also no digital backup available to you to re-download direct from iTunes should you have an issue with the computer you redeem the code on.  Of the 50+ movies I have redeemed via iTunes, this is the ONLY MOVIE that is limited in this regard.  I reached out to iTunes thinking it was bugged, but they referred me back to the publisher as they control the rights to the  movie.  As it stands, the only way to get this to a portable device is to direct sync it with iTunes and there is NO streaming possible via AppleTV.  I know, first world problems... but still, it is extremely annoying if you want to have your digital content be as portable as possible.

I've watched this over and over again. Who wouldn't want a four digit IQ? I know I would.

I saw what I considered to be a couple of plot anomalies though. One was that if he was doubling his money every day, he could have multiplied it by at least 1024 times in just ten more business days. If he was willing to wait for twenty more business days, he would have multiplied his money by 1048576 times. To me, that seems more than fast enough. If he was starting out with a few thousand dollars, he could easily have been a billionaire without borrowing any money from the greedy thug. Of course, that would have made the movie enormously different and not nearly as dramatic. He wouldn't have needed to have anything to do with Carl Van Loon either. And $40,000,000 after two months (42 or 43 business days) work? Aside from market reaction, he could have multiplied his money by approximately 7.9668296 * 10^12 times. Obviously, the writer's ideas on the mathematics of exponential growth left a lot to be desired.

I've known, admired, and envied some very intelligent people in my time, and I wished I could have thought of the same things they did. While I guessed that their IQ's were at least a couple of standard deviations higher than mine, I can scarcely imagine what a four digit IQ would be like. And that brings me to my next anomaly.

Assuming he got a five times (from 20% of his brain to 100% according to Vernon Gant and "It works better if you're already smart." -- so I guessed an IQ of about 130, otherwise Eddie Morra's down and out writer character would not have been plausible) multiplication of his IQ, that would probably have taken him to about 650. To get to 1000 (the lowest four digit IQ), his mental metabolic rate probably would have had to have been stepped up to about 1.54 times it's normal level too. That seems a bit implausible as well given that Vern spoke only of an access boost. But, in contrast to what I just said, his ex-wife Mellisa said she quit because she was afraid of burnout, so perhaps there could have been a mental metabolic increase after all.

Everything considered, flaws and all, this was a very engaging movie and well worth the purchase. No buyer's remorse here, I'm glad I bought it.

== Spoilers ahead ==

Limitless made for a fun, Friday-night romp, but ten minutes after leaving the movie theater, I realized its plot relied on idiotic coincidences and presented a disturbing, pro-drug message.  It's too bad, really, that the writing was so questionable, because the acting and cinematography were quite strong.

Eddie Morra (Bradley Cooper) is a struggling, non-household-name writer who nevertheless has been paid an advance on a book he hasn't written yet.  (Okaaay, but we'll let that one go for the moment.)  Just when he's about to drain down the toilet of despair, an old friend introduces him to NZT, a drug that allows him to utilize his brain's full potential.  You know the old wive's tale, of course: we mortals are cursed to only use a small fraction of our brain cells because the rest of it is preoccupied with things like pornography.  But NZT, the wonder drug, allows Eddie to fire up his full 100 percent.  Suddenly, he can place his order with a waiter in a foreign language; and gee, we've never ever seen that in a movie before.  He finishes his novel in four days -- four days! -- as computer-generated letters and numbers rain down upon him and his word processor to show us the miracle of this manna-from-heaven intelligence.

Soon, he makes a killing on the stock market and meets the financial world's godfather, played by Robert De Niro, whose name, Carl Van Loon, is surely coincidental to the character's being a loon.  Eddie's ex-girlfriend, Lindy (Abbie Cornish), falls in love with this new persona and rewards him with sex.

Eddie also makes a killing in the form of a Courtney Love lookalike whom he murders during a drug-induced blackout.  So he uses his money to hire a high-rolling defense lawyer who -- coincidentally! -- works for Carl Van Loon's arch-nemesis, who employs a psycho henchman who -- coincidentally! -- has been following Eddie around all this time.

More hijinks ensue.  The cameraman goes crazy with a continuous-zoom effect that travels the length of Manhattan island and ends up sprayed all over the seat in front of me.  Eddie beats his murder rap, the Loon is outsmarted, Eddie is on the road to the presidency, and he flawlessly orders another meal in a foreign language he doesn't know.

And did I mention that the movie starts at the very climax of the story until Eddie jumps in as a voiceover to say that he'll now show us how he arrived at this point?

What's most disturbing about this movie is that it validates the drug culture.  It shows, again and again, that we're not smart enough or athletic enough to solve our problems without pills.  Eddie is rewarded, repeatedly, for his habit: he becomes rich, he gets the girl back, he gets away with murder, and he's set onto the road of "limitless" fame and fortune.

Oh, he says he's off the drug by the end of the movie -- he doesn't need it anymore -- presumably because he just thought his way out of it with his advanced intelligence.  After all, that's what Charlie Sheen teaches us, isn't it, that you can just blink your eyes and tap your ruby slippers to cure yourself of substance abuse.  Even if you believe that's possible -- and I hope by my tone you realize I don't -- Eddie's drug-free status at the end of the movie doesn't justify how he arrived there, which was by traveling the road of pharmaceutical assistance.

Limitless is a slick-looking movie.  It's mostly fun to watch.  But it's kind of like a big candy bar -- maybe one laced with LSD.  The side effects and the bad aftertaste aren't worth it.

Is it possible that the mind could be totally tapped for all its potential? This movie explores that premise with the usual corny and false idea that a person only uses a small fraction of their brain. We all use 100% of our brains. It is just that some brains work better than others. Given that minor flaw, I loved the story and wished I could take a pill that made me a super genius. Dream on. But it was instructive, I thought, that given a super brain doesn't automatically make one more moral or able to make good choices. That seems to be a different power altogether.

*** This review may contain spoilers ***

 'Limitless' is one of those entertaining thrillers that (despite its ill-conceived ending), will appeal to the majority of ordinary males who have fantasies of becoming the kind of male women seem to automatically gravitate to: the alpha male. Indeed, the film's protagonist, Eddie Morra, the down and out novelist played by Bradley Cooper, represents an exaggerated version of the kind of situation, the average guy finds himself in, on a daily basis.

While most guys aren't down to their last buck like Morra, they can certainly can identify with his great dissatisfaction in the inability to achieve success in a career. It's not like Morra is some bum off the street: he's got an agent but has writer's block; the average guy can relate to Morra's inability to reach his potential. The same applies to women: Morra does have a very good-looking girlfriend, Lindy--but because he doesn't reach his potential and ends up projecting a negative image, she has no guilt feelings about dumping him.

'Limitless' allows the average male to indulge in the fantasy of becoming an instant alpha male without developing the skills. When Eddie runs into his ex-brother-in-law who gives him the illegal medication, 'NZT', we're ready to break into Act 2 and watch how Eddie is transformed. Perhaps the best scene in the movie is when Eddie must turn his brow-beating landlady around after she constantly screams at him for not paying his rent. Instead of adopting the motivational social skills of the ordinary schlub, the NZT allows Eddie to tap his full cognitive potential. Not only does he help the landlady with her paper for law school but also ends up bedding her without even trying.

A montage with voice-over allows us to see what else Eddie accomplishes 'under the influence', including learning how to play difficult classical music pieces on the piano as well as mastering multiple languages in a matter of a few days. Instead of turning into a mensch, Eddie decides to model himself after Gordon Gekko. He starts as a day trader and begins amassing some money and this is where perhaps the first plot hole appears in the film. If he's such a genius, why does he have to borrow $100,000 from a Russian loan shark? During a voice-over, Eddie claims he needs the money fast but given his talents, couldn't the newly transformed Eddie have made that kind of money in a week or two? His financial success leads Lindy to change her mind about him and she's back in his arms in no time. Eddie also insinuates himself into the business world of business tycoon Carl Van Loon (another average performance by Robert De Niro) and is on the verge of earning millions, advising Van Loon as he's about to complete a merger with Atwood, a business rival. Eddie's transformation now appears complete.

Screenwriter Leslie Dixon manages to keep things moving even after Eddie's transformation is finished. Since there is a limited supply of NZT, all the really bad guys are after Eddie including the loan shark and a stalker. What's more there are very bad side effects to this medication. Eddie is shocked to see his ex-wife, who is going downhill from NZT's side effects as well as discovering previous users have either died or are physically debilitated. Eddie also can't recall where he is for 18 hours and later he's implicated in a murder of a woman in a hotel.

There's also an exciting scene where the stalker goes after Lindy. She's seemingly cornered in Central Park (of all places) by the Stalker, but Eddie advises her to take one pill of NZT, which allows her to figure out how to stop her pursuer. Her escape is exciting but contains one ugly misstep: she grabs a little girl who's skating on an ice rink, and uses her as a human machete--slashing her pursuer with the blade of the little girl's skate (I wonder why no one chased her and why she wasn't initially charged with child endangerment).

The second act crisis is rather perfunctory, with Eddie going toe to toe with the Russian loan shark and his henchmen. There a few twists and turns in this confrontation, especially when Eddie runs out of his NZT, stabs the loan shark and is forced to drink his blood in order to get NZT back into his system.

While a good part of this is somewhat unbelievable, it all adds up to some breezy entertainment. Unfortunately, Leslie Dixon, the film's screenwriter opts for a typical Hollywood ending, which dilutes the film's overall impact. We're asked to accept that Eddie somehow overcomes the addiction to NZT and retains his mental abilities--even though everybody else becomes addicted and goes downhill after being unable resist, after taking one pill. I also wondered why Lindy did not succumb to the effects of NZT and become an addict (I guess since she's one of the 'good ones', she has the willpower to resist).

Finally, why should we really root for Eddie? Has he done anything good to help humanity? In the end he's a politician who rejects Van Loon, who wants to control him, even after he becomes president. But Eddie still is sleazy--after all he is a politician (not a brain surgeon!). A better ending would have Eddie sacrificing himself to save Lindy--penitence for his decision to use drugs and suck up to bad guy Van Loon.

I enjoyed 'Limitless' up to a point. It's a fast-paced thriller, undone mainly by a cheap ending, that makes little sense.

This film deals with a subject that hasn't often been addressed in films.  What if there was a drug that could enhance your intelligence and give you superior ability?  Would it be worthwhile to take it?  What would be the consequences to your livelihood, your relationships, your personality, your character?

All of these issues are explored by the film and in a very realistic way.  The character development, in Eddie's case, is excellent.  Bradley Cooper(Eddie) does an outstanding job of going from a frumpy, down-and-out, aspiriring writer to a slick and competent human being. Then the crash he experiences when he goes through withdrawal from the drug is quite realistic.  I would also say that the script is excellent. I like the way it explores some of the more personal aspects of psychoactive drug use, like "Am I really ME when I'm on the drug or am I someone else?". The various scenarios (ie. Eddie and his girlfriend, Eddie and a Russian loan shark, Eddie in a day trading firm, Eddie and the corporate big wigs) all come across quite credibly and smoothly.  You know that this is the way that people act and talk.

The film does have some plot holes, like

1)  The police certainly would have searched Eddie's person and found the money and the stash of pills when they came to
  the apartment.  That probably would have ended the story right there.

2)  It's doubtful that someone would have framed Eddie for murder just so that they could get the pills.  Why would they think
  that it would work?

3)  It's not likely that a person as smart as Eddie would not have paid back the loan shark, knowing that his life depended
  on it.

4)  Why would Eddie even bother going to a loan shark at all?  With his enhanced abilities he could have made millions without that kind of help.

These are just a few holes in the story but I'm sure there are others.

What concerns me more is how the medication affected Eddie.  I'm concerned that he wasn't more upset about the murdered woman and the role (even unknowingly) he might have played in it.  I'm concerned that he didn't have more compassion for Hank Atwood and didn't try to save his life.  I'm concerned that while vacationing in the Carribean, he comes up with a "vision" for his life, but his "vision" basically involves making millions in day trading.  I'm wondering if this is actually part the cautionary tale and that one of the effects of enhanced ability is a lack of concern for others and for the betterment of society.  Does enhanced ability just turn a self-absorbed person into a more successful and adaptable self-absorbed person?  What are the consequences of that?  Maybe that gives some credence to him not paying the loan shark.  Perhaps he was so intoxicated with himself and his new abilities that he neglected to pay.

What makes this subject interesting is that a certain class of this type of drug already exists.  They're called amphetamines.  Back in the early twentieth century when amphetamines were first introduced they were considered the wonder drugs of the century.  People who struggled with fatigue, depression, timidity and poor self image took these drugs and experienced an immediate turn-a-round.  They became more productive and successful at work.  They were able to work longer hours without fatigue.  They became more socially engaging and self-assured.  Their family lives became more stable.  But there was a price.  We eventually discovered that these drugs were highly addictive and that users had to keep upping the dose to get the desired effect.  We also discovered that if too much were taken it could cause psychosis.  The wonder drugs turned out to be not so wonderful.

I suspect this is the case with most if not all performance enhancing drugs.  Sooner or later, there's going to be a reckoning to pay.  That's why I really didn't like the ending of the film.  Eddie's lab perfects the pill to such a degree that he doesn't have to take it any more.  The enhancing effects of the drug are now permanent and his life is now happy ever after.  Oh please!  Wouldn't it be better to have him come down off the meds and learn to cope with his natural imperfections?  I don't know.  I don't know what the ending should be, but I don't think it should be "NZT solved all of my problems".

Unless, of course, there's going to be a Limitless 2.  Hmm.......

This Fincheresquely-filmed movie starring fellow barrel-maker Bradley is a lot of fun and deals with some very interesting ideas; but in order to preserve the mass-appeal necessary to make back its budget, the implications of these ideas are sometimes given short shrift.

For example, how are people's motivations affected by increased brain performance?  Are we to assume that since Bradley was a 'good guy' to begin with he wants to use his 4-digit IQ (good lord) to help humanity as a politician, and that the Russian 'bad guy' only has the acquisition of filthy lucre as his aim after becoming smart?  In other words, that a person's deepest desires remain unaffected by intelligence?  This is too simple and black-and-white; but it's understandable because these kinds of questions are better handled along the arc of a TV series rather than a 2-hour film.  Even so, I'd have preferred to see Bradley's newfound cognitive skills lead him to the selfish core of what had been his writing ambition and turn him into a monstrous cult leader, and for the Russian to have become a philanthropic engineer bent on inventing a process to provide cheap renewable energy.

Another more relevant issue, though, is why does big pharma seem to be more interested in turning off our thoughts and feelings than in turning them on?  One interpretation of the film is that turning them on would precipitate lost time, headaches, and eventual death; but really the film doesn't address this question at all.  And that's what limits it more than anything else.

A far better film than I gave it credit for being, `Limitless' was one of those rare instances where a preconceived notion of a film is completely flipped after seeing it finally.  My best friend was ranting and raving over vacation about this movie being one of his favorites, and I kind of laughed because I just can't take Bradley Cooper seriously (this was before I finally saw `Silver Linings Playbook' yesterday, so bear with me).  That, and conceptually this just seemed so silly.

It is silly, but that isn't the point.

The basic premise is that an aspiring writer suffering from severe writer's block and lack of any funds falls into good luck (sort of) when he meets up with his ex-brother-in-law who was a former drug dealer and now is, allegedly, going legit for a pharmaceutical company pimping a drug that unleashes your brains full potential.  He gives our protagonist a free hit, which does its job remarkably well, and soon he's aching for more.  A murder and a burnout later and he's scrambling to keep his addiction, grow his funds and win back his girlfriend, all the while wooing a business prospect.  But things are falling apart, people are tracking him down and a certain thug is trying his hardest to get his hands on more pills.

The key to this film working is turning off your brain and allowing the director, Neil Burger, to warp your mind.  The film is executed really well.  For an action thriller, this nails all the right moments to create something engaging and thrilling.  The lighting, the sets, the pacing, the edits and the use of music is all key to propelling the film along.  The cast is decent enough, with Cooper surprising me with the amount of depth he brought to a well written role.  Abbie Cornish is wasted entirely, and De Niro phones in every minute of his screen time, but like I said, the star of the show is Burger.

I honestly wanted to hate this, but I liked it quite a bit.
While it isn't scientifically accurate. (The whole point being using 100% of your brain at a time, which would be called a seizure) The movie does have an interesting plot.

In some ways, this move is similar to the movie Contagion where it provides a entirely plausible scenario to an incredibly unlikely biological aberration. Like the book Flowers for Algernon, Limitless provides a window into the theoretical limits of our own brain power.  What would it mean if the average person could take a pill that would allow he/she to harness every neuron.  Pretty eye opening.

It is my favorite because I have lived with natural brain enhancement caused by bipolar illness and I know what it feels like to be this way. The actor does a fantastic job of portraying someone in mania, the good kind, and how your brain sped up works. I once tested with an IQ of 225 while manic. Of course I had a great day solving all my problems and anyone elses. But you gotta come down sometime. . . and that's in this movie as well. Watch and enjoy. Now you know what its like to be bipolar or multi-polar as I like to call it.

See the movie first before reading this. 'Limitless' is one of those movies that you can show to anyone and know they will be hooked from beginning to end. This movie has all the fun stuff in it, suspense, action, romance told at a brisk pace, but also lots of life and business lessons; Our hero Eddie gets access to 100% of his brain by using a smart pill called NTZ. He tells us via narration,"Everything I'd ever read, seen and heard was now organized and available." After hooking up with higher caliber friends (his useless relationships are "better forgotten and put away in mothballs," he says) and going to  Puerto Valletta, Eddie says,"Mere lounging wasn't enough. Suddenly I knew what I needed to do. But it would take money to get there."

In the beginning of the film, when Eddie is standing on the ledge of the building ready to jump, he talks about "Wanting to make an impact on the world, instead of the pavement." When explaining his book in the bar, Eddie mentions a 'utopian society.'  So we can guess that his final goal might be helping the world. When Eddie is accused of having 'delusions of grandeur' he retorts with, "I have an actual recipe for grandeur." Ah, a plan. Definite plans get definite results. Indefinite plans do not get 'indefinite results', they get NO results. Eddie says, "I was clear. I knew what I needed to do, and how to do it."

Eddie says, "There are moments in your life when you cross a bridge and know that your old life is over." And while a high level of success is necessary to express our true selves, Eddie cautions us with, "We are all wired to over reach. Look at history, all the countries that ruled the world. No one stopped and said, 'We've got France, Poland, a big Swiss bank account. Let's not invade Russia in the winter. Let's go home, pop a beer and live on the interest.'" Yes, better not fulfill the Peter Principle and rise to our level of our incompetence.

DeNiro makes a good point about earning your power by experience. He tells Eddie: "Your super intellect is a gift from God, but you didn't earn it because you're careless with your power, flashing it around like a trust fund child. You never had to earn it year by year. You don't know how to assess your competition because you never had to compete."

Finally, Eddie's success in now internalized and natural. When he speaks to a waiter in Chinese, his girlfriend looks at him in awe. Eddie turns to her, sees her expression and says, "What?"

Leaving the theater after seeing 'Limitless' I heard some guy say, "I wish I had the pill." But all that Eddie does in this movie can be accomplished without the pill. See for yourself.
Very original movie. Exciting premise that explores what our minds could be capable of. Interesting mix of thriller, sci-fi, and some comedy. Good sound track.

Limitless is one of these rare films, where the preview doesn't give you a clue as to how good it really is. I saw this because the movie I wanted to see wasn't playing until 11, and I honestly didn't expect much from it. What I got was a visual masterpiece, with some of the best camera work I've ever seen, and an amazing story that was so much more than some guy and his magic pill. It's intense, shocking, and unique. Bradley Cooper really makes the movie. He FINALLY lets go of his super cool, good looking guy image, and really shows the audience that he can act! This movie was a breath of fresh air and I can't wait til it comes out on DVD so I can see it again!

This is the unrated Extended Cut which gives two possible endings depending on which one you choose it is happy or sort of not.  After watching this movie I tracked down the book that this was originated from, The Dark Fields which later they renamed to the name of this movie.

The book sheds more light into the drug AZT and gives a more grim picture than what the movie version goes into.  I do not know if the book "Limitless" is word for word the same as "The Dark Fields"  or if the movie titled book is the movie in print form.  I just went and tracked down the original title, which is much darker than the movie and goes into more aspects of the character and events that the movie glosses over.  The movie ending and the book ending are different and the story is slanted different as well so if you watched the movie go read the book as it adds more to the experience and vice versa.

This movie is one of my top favorite movies. The acting is good and I think they did a good job with casting the main character, he seems to fit the role.

It doesn't exist and if it did go read the book and it will scare the hell out of you to ever want to try something like this for real.  It is a MOVIE, it's entertainment only!

I really enjoyed the movie, it even had a cliff hanger at the beginning. He haw just a average guy that had to cope with new intelligence... A lot of people wanted it, and he coped with it and won basicly. There was excitment adventure, and sex.

a great film. Glad to have it. Service was excellent and I'd order again. Rarely watch movies over and even more unusual to purchase one! Worth the price. :)

There really isn't much I can say about this movie that hasn't already been said by many other reviewers. I didn't really expect a whole lot from this movie, but I found that I thoroughly enjoyed it. It's interesting to imagine what people would be capable of if they really could use the full potential of the human mind. Would it just be a mattter of heightened senses? The ability to rapidly scan and absorb and process information? The ability to mentally construct complex patterns, systems or ideas in short amounts of time? The ability to solve almost any problem? Or would it allow for almost super-natural powers such as telekinesis or telepathy? Who really knows? At least this movie does a good job exploring that concept and does it in an entertaining way. This is one I will definitely watch again. Very intriguing!

I love this film as to how and what would occur if there was a drug out there that expanded our capacities... and just purchased the book as well.. wow it was based on a book, the authors first novel!!!

If you never watched this movie and you consider yourself a mainstream movie watcher and generally are somebody that likes movies, then you will probably like this. If you are a critic and require an "artsy" and "award-worthy" component of some sort than you possibly may not care for this movie.

The premise is we only use 20% of our brains, and what we would be like if we could access the whole thing. The main character basically does just that, and it makes him feel limitless.  It was a fun movie and I believe Bradley Cooper is appropriately casted for the role.

Would recommend to those who haven't seen it.
I love this movie because I love every rags to ritches story and many of us can relate to be stuck in a rut.

At what cost do you put yourself on the line to say, I can fit in,this is where I belong? All it takes is one pill, but then after the high wears off you search for that high again. At what cost, natural or induced?
Simply an awesome movie - I would highly recommend as its both entertaining and enlighting since the difference between an incredible life and a normal life lies within the mind.

This was a fast paced movie with an interesting plot.  I was lost in the story line and trying to figure out the mystery of what would happen next.  I watched it alone and I was jumping out of my seat.
This is worth watching for sure. I found myself wishing I had a few of those pills myself ! You will not regret renting or buying this one, had a few good twists that I didn't fully see coming.
This is an interesting flick, plenty of action, well done, love the actors, and that makes it worth watching a few times

What would you do with a pill that gave you superhuman intelligence? Bring about world peace? Solve hunger or poverty? Teach your brilliant ideas to others? No, not if you are the hero of this movie. He goes for mere selfish sex, money, and power.

I like a profound theme in my movies. This one could have been a profound and meaningful tale about a modern Faust or Icarus. But it chose a cheaper, more shallow path.

True, this movie was fun thrill ride. which I enjoyed more via streaming because I could fast forward the sex and violence. I just wish it had chosen a more profound theme.

This movie is about a lazy slacker who solves all his problems by taking a dangerous drug. I would have preferred that it had been about a lazy slacker to tries to solve all his problem by taking a dangerous drug but instead learns some wisdom, even some humility.

Though this is a movie centered around the taking of drugs which I absolutely abhor in life, how awesome to take one little pill and have all the mental clarity in the world... to unlock your truest potential. Amazing and I'm thrilled that he ended up smarter than the drugs. Makes me feel good about owning this movie.

Where was all the media for this movie? Was it a direct to video release? I totally missed this at the box office and was pleasantly surprised when I watched it. It's an original plot that is intriguing and believable. Bradley Cooper was outstanding. He deserved a People's Choice Award nomination at the very least. Robert DeNiro is still GREAT and was a joy to watch in this movie. This movie has the makings of a sleeper hit. I'd like to see the earnings for this movie a year from now. My wife had seen the movie some time ago on Amazon and said she enjoyed it even better the second time through. I will definitely watch this movie again. If you enjoy a creative and unique storyline, action, suspense and thrills, this movie is for you!

"Limitless" may not be anything special but it's a heckuva thrill ride.  Director Neil Berger keeps the proceedings moving at a breakneck pace that causes you to stop for intermittent breaths.  Leslie Dixon's ingenious script is full of neat twists and turns with some deliciously cheeky humor.  Bradley Cooper's star continues to rise with his charismatic turn as a burned out writer turned super genius(not of the Wile E. Coyote variety) with the aid of some non-approved by the FDA pharmaceuticals.  Robert DeNiro steals virtually every scene he is in as a Wall Street power broker whose dual intentions are to tap into Cooper's zeitgeist and destroy him in the process.  Abbie Cornish is reminiscent of the ice blondes that Hitchcock favored in his heyday.  So grab a couple Monsters and enjoy the show.
I love this movie...it makes me want to try a little harder to use a little more of my brain...without drugs of course...anything manmade will always have negative side effects...period!

I enjoyed this movie quite a bit. I saw it when it came out, and recently rented it again. Without giving anything away, I always wondered about what happened to the people that first developed the drug.
The movie was exactly what we expected. We enjoyed it very much. I would recommend it to anyone to watch.

"Limitless" gets off to a strong start - a dicey character hands out "smart pills" that really work. Pop one, and you're suddenly brilliant. In the case of this down-and-out writer, that means not just getting started on that novel stalled because of writer's block, but finishing in just a few days. Of course, being that brilliant becomes addictive.

The story moves along well. First, his dealer ends up dead. (What would a smrt guy do with that clue?) Then,to finance his venture, he borrows from the local loan shark (not so smart). Next, he flaunts his new-found ability as day trader, building up his financial head of steam - and I have to wonder whether taking such a high profile so fast was really a good idea.

Things get out of hand, though. The loan shark gets his hands on the pill, and dicovers that being a smart crook is more fun than just being a crook. And there are side effects - the kind that kill not just you, but maybe other people, too ...

This should have been an August movie. Just a few too many things seem just a bit too implausible for anything but a silly season flick. But, if you stifle your own intelligence, it's enjoyable enough.

-- wiredweird

Movies like this make you suspend your rational thinking and just go with it.  Who wouldn't want to take the pill, for a chance to achieve all your dreams.  Maybe that's the rub, we aren't supposed to.

What a concept!  Would u do a drug that made you use your whole brain instead of the tiny portion you actually use?  The action is fast-paced because the thinking is fast-paced!  I disagree with review that said it slowed or got murky in latter part.  The movie goes up and down, fast and slow, which matches the experience of the drug.  When it seems withdrawal may become a problem, the action/plot becomes frantic.  The action truly does follow the drug experience and Bradley Cooper does it well, alternating between peppy and brilliant, and messy, slow and confused.  He portrays a good "junkie" even SPOILER ALERT going so far as to lap the blood of a another guy doing the drug, when he is desperate for a plan to get out of trouble.  Think fast! Get a plan!  Drop a pill!  I'm sure Big Pharma has been workin' on it for a while now, and it will cost!
Watched on my computer 3 times. A great movie for the ambitious person who may be in a slump. Motivates in a twisted way. What you need is already inside you. Great music too!
Very good and advisable to buy. Thank you very much. The movie is very good. It is necessary to see her!

I truly regret seeing Limitless! The violence is excessive and disturbing. PG-13 doesn't mean very much anymore! The current movie rating system in the United States is an absolute joke and it should be abolished! Have a sex/violence activity rating system that's practical! At least that kind of rating system would be much more honest! When stabbing out a man's eye and making him blind (he was already blind in the other eye) is PG-13, then what's next? Scraping an eye out with a spoon? See:War Junkie: One Man's Addiction to the Worst Places on Earth and The Lucifer Principle: A Scientific Expedition into the Forces of History
The picture that is advertised is not the blue ray that you will recieve.. no digital copy / dvd .. will not do business with them again
I love this movie! Bradley cooper is awesome in it and the plot keeps you on your toes with twists and turns through out.

Just rented this from Netflix and was forced to sit through umpteen commercials for their other pathetic films ... from last year no less~!  Do the studios really believe this is a good way to sell their products?!  Suffice it to say, that I did NOT view this film, just sent it back to Netflix.  I will avoid 20th Century Fox films as often as possible as I do with their television programs.

I'm not going to do any spoilers, or even go in depth as to what the the story-line is about. There are plenty of reviews that have already taken care of that. I will mention my thoughts on the premise though.

This movie had already been out from quite awhile before I saw it. I hadn't seen a trailer or even knew what it was about. Perhaps that is why I enjoyed it, I had no preconceived expectations. I rarely enjoy Hollywood movies anymore. I watch mainly foreign an independent films. The reason for this, those films have a higher satisfaction rate of getting what you expect. Not over-hyped movies featuring overpaid actors where everything good to see in the movie is pieced together into a 30 second trailer!

Bradly Cooper does in outstanding job in this "what if" film. What if I could be a success? What if it were possible to have my dreams come true? What if I became a different person ... good or bad? Most of us has experienced these what if or if only moments. If we had a magic pill that helped us achieve our dreams, would we take it? If we did, would it change our personality or affect our moral decisions? Bradly Coopers character gets to ask those questions and receive the answers. Will he like the answers he gets? Will he fly like Icarus or spiral out of control? Where will this sudden realization take him? Will he stay on that road or take another one? Will it change him for better or for worse? What happens when other people want what you have?

This movie highlights what are each of us may be capable of under the right circumstances. How the choices we make and continue to make shapes our lives.

If you found my review helpful, please vote. Thank You.

Brilliant movie, The story of having everything you could ever dream about in the blink of an eye is pure genius, Bradley Cooper & the Legend Robert Deniro are dynamic together. All in all this movie is quite inspirational and self motivating.

An unsuccessful writer takes a smart pill that lets him access the unused corners of his brain. The drug leads to all sorts of problems, including addiction, lost time, withdrawal, involvement with thuggish criminals and rogue corporate elements, not to mention the issues the drug creates with the writer's girlfriend. Fortunately, being super-smart helps the writer navigate his way through these perils.

Limitless is stylish, smart, cynical, twisted, and engrossing, filled with energetic action and gore that works seamlessly into a well-conceived story. Some spectacular visuals kept my eyes glued to the screen. The performances are all strong, but it's great to see DeNiro give a surprisingly subtle performance in a supporting role. There was nothing about this movie I didn't like. 4 1/2 stars.

I liked it a lot, good story line, lots of action and great ending.
Liked it so much that I watched it a second time right after viewing it the first time.
I don't want to spoil anything for you, so all I'll say is if you're one of those people like myself that can figure out what's going to happen in a movie within about 15 minutes or less of watching it, you'll like this movie. The reason is because you can't figure the route it taking. I think anyone has used a story-line like this one before in a movie or book.
Make sure to buy the Unrated Extended Cut version, it's worth it
It is a poorly developed story that cannot make itself make sense.  Film degrades into unneeded violence.  Waste of time.

This film is a nice change of pace, something different than the norm. A man takes a magic pill and transforms into a genius but not without consequences and one big sht storm. The acting was good, story good and unique, direction good, vibrant colors, cinematography good, dialog really good. Overall 4-1/2 Stars. I will always tell it like I see it.
Scott M

Who doesn't want to be Albert Einstein or make over $2 million in the stock market as a day-trader - right after taking an experimental drug? This exciting fantasy tells of a man who was down and out on luck, until his brother-in-law (?) gives him an experimental drug that claims to boost one's brain power. Just when the daring experimenter starts to ride the waves to instant intellectual powers, stardom, popularity and riches, he discovers that unwanted attention comes alongside the road to fame and riches. Is the thrilling ride worth all the risks?

Good fast pace movie.  Really good and has a little bit of everything.  It's mystical, it has the mob, drugs, fantasy, lots of twists.  Very interesting and really opens up your thinging to what if?  I loved it and you will too. When he takes the drug you are in for a surprise, the screen does an interesting thing. Loved the Blue Ray although I didn't notice it until he took the drug and then WOW!  Hold on it's quite a ride.

This is a great movie.  Bradley Cooper does a good job of playing a down and out character who makes it to the top...granted he had 'a little' help getting there. This movie has a bit of a "Wall Street" movie vibe, which I also liked. If you can get this movie for a deal then it is worth it.

I bought this because my son says it's the best movie he's seen on Net Flicks.  Nonetheless, I love a good suspense/sci-fi story and this fits the bill.  Moves fast, entertaining with a great story line. DeNiro is great (as a big player on Wall Street) and Cooper does a good job portraying the ordinary guy who after taking NZT (brain enhancement drug), finds himself an instant genius, with a Midas touch! The women, the fast cars, the fame and the millions made in days (playing the stock market, etc). Of course there's the downside (what happens when he runs out), mixed with the dangerous drug dealer who wants not only his front money but an endless supply of the same drug!  A lot of action, great effects, and if course who wouldn't love the color of Brad Cooper's neon blue eyes (on NZT)!

The ending is perfect - Definitely worth watching!

Bradley Cooper makes a decent fist of his role here, as the down and out writer struggling to find inspiration and motivation, who is introduced to a new pill.. this wonder pill allows the brain to access not just the 20% we use, but the whole brain - making him smarter, able to access every memory, and his abilities seem.. well, limitless.  Alas, this performance comes with a price.  The drug is not strictly legal, and he is not the only one who wants it.
It's a good hook, and broadly speaking the movie does a decent job of wringing a thriller out of it, and on the way makes some commentary on addiction - whether it is to drugs or to power or to consumerism - though unfortunately loses a lot of the bite as it progresses to an increasingly predictable thriller denouement.  Effects and editing are cleverly (if rather flashily) used to emphasise the heightened awareness, creating an oddly hallucinogenic mood as he transitions from down and out to super perceptive charmer and wheeler dealer.  In a supporting role Abbie Cornish does fine, and Robert de Niro shows up and says his lines in a throwaway role which seems almost perfunctorily added on.  Presumably he does just enough to get on the front cover to help sales, but it helps neither his career, or the film.
It's pretty exciting and relatively action packed, but with not too much violence.  All in all, any looming ridiculousness is staved off by a pace which doesn't allow you to think too much.  A shame perhaps, as with braver hands this might have been more of an interesting commentary rather than a thriller.. but it still works.  The directors name is Neil Burger.. perhaps if you consider the movie as cinematic fast food, it's a success.  It never felt like it had been put together by a masterchef, but it satisfied me at the time, reliably entertained me, even if I didn't remember much about it the next day.
I wasn't sure if I would enjoy this movie, but after watching it and the alternate endings, it was a great movie!  A bit of love, fighting, and great tactical moves.

interesting if you like exciting movies without a lot of violence. Bradley Cooper does a good job, but it's also not his best acting job. Interesting for types that like to get ahead and are interested in seeing the consequences of using less traditional means.

Both my wife and I found this movie to be very enjoyable.  It held our attention, the plot was good, as were the action scenes.  I would recommend this movie.

Very creative spin on a familiar story line. Unlock the potential of the human brain. What's creative you ask? Typically it is suggested that once the brain is working at full capacity, the subject has unlimited learning potential. As in, the subject can acquire large amounts of NEW information. What's new about Limitless is that the subject is able to unlock information already acquired through encounters and life experiences. Very cool.
This movie has a strong cast and is well acted. Very well done and great dialog. Highly recommend!

The previews cannot be fast forwarded, skipped, proceed to top or main menu so if you stop the movie you have to sit through 9 minutes of previews before you get to the menu.  This is a deal breaker.  Let the Blu Ray MFGs (not it's not dirty but manufacturers) know this is not acceptable.  A dead horse head in their bed should do.

Guy whose life is on the road to nowhere gets given a drug that fires up the brain - every scrap of information that ever came your way in life is suddenly organized and instantly accessible - anything new you want to learn is absorbed in a snap.  Talk about an addicting drug! There's not a lot to the plot - it's all in how it all plays out and I don't want to give anything away.

If the trailer appeals to you, then you should enjoy this movie. A solid 4-stars. (I try to reserve 5-stars for the ones that you want everyone you know to see and you yourself want to watch many times over because the characters are so endearing etc.)

A very SMART movie.  Good acting, good story, ZERO DISAPPOINTMENT.

"Limitless" is one of those dopey thrillers that comes along every year, where the filmmaker tries to supplant "smart" with "hip" and "stylish."  It's not much of the latter two either, a "Fight Club" redux, only this time instead of a split personality focused on violence it's a no personality focused on super intelligence.  Or super memory.  I'm not sure because the story never really shows the character being smart so much as acting like a human version of a computer, accessing and processing ideas at the speed of light without really stopping to reason much out.  Bradley Cooper -- who looks like Matthew McConaughey and Larry Fine had a baby -- lopes along playing a loser named Eddie pretending to be a writer and generally letting his days slide out from under him effortlessly.  His life is a trainwreck until a chance encounter (aren't they all?) with his ex brother in law introduces him to a pill that boosts his mental abilities to the point that he's learning languages in hours and making millions in the stock market.  That attracts a lot of publicity, one of the first signs that he isn't too bright, along with loans from the Russian mob, another sign, that cause his life to spiral out of control.  "Limitless" dodges all the meaningful questions of what would happen if someone suddenly discovered his mind worked better than anyone else's, the sort of thing novels like "Flowers for Algernon" and its film adaptation tackled 40 years ago. when stories like these were imaginative . . . instead, it lets Eddie act like an out of control frat boy who suddenly discovers sex, drugs, and rock and roll.  Robert DeNiro phones in a performance as a corporate raider type.  Worse are the women in the story.  Abbie Cornish, for instance, plays the standard shallow girlfriend who doesn't want anything more to do with Eddie when he is a loser but is immediately charmed when he becomes a winner -- a particularly unbelievable scene happens when Eddie, suffering from withdrawal, staggers into her workplace, to the understandable shock of everyone, and then remains on the floor while she goes to get his pills and is chased by a knife-wielding assassin . . . all while staying on her cell phone with him.  Just another day at the office I suppose.  It's worse later when Eddie has to get his hit of the drug from a disgusting source.  "Limitless" plays like a 20-year-old's understanding of the world, which is to say it is about chases and one-ups instead of anything meaningful.  No one expects a thriller nowadays to be particularly mature, but "Limitless" is, in fact, limitless in its childishness.

When I watched this, I quickly got the feeling that it was a sort of retelling of the Legend of Faust. He gets it all: money, women, power, in exchange for his life as the pill slowly makes him sicker.  I thought the ending would be of him dying or something, so the actual ending kind of upset me.
The moral of the story: cheaters always win. Plus, like someone else pointed out, it was almost like they were promoting drug use. YES, I watched the whole movie; I know that it was a mind enhancing drug that allowed you to use more of your brain power, but it was basically like any other drug. It made him sick and addicted.
 But using the powers that the drug gave him, he sidestepped his punishment (death) even though he pretty much deserved it. What he didn't deserve was to live on with no consequences. It's not only the moral issues that bothered me, but also the fact that they left plot points unfinished. Like what happened to his ex-wife and who killed that woman? It was a rather interesting movie, just morally unethical. I wouldn't advise showing this movie to children.

Read some of the reviews and figured I would check this out and wow, am I glad that I did! Was thoroughly entertained throughout the entire movie. Would highly recommend this to anyone looking for something out of the ordinary and thought provoking.

"Limitless" serves only to irresponsibly indulge fantasies of those who want to be rich, attractive, and sexually active.  That being said, a lot of people will like it, but I couldn't recommend it to anyone.  The protagonist pursues drugs, money, sex, and power with little restraint while managing to escape a lot of natural negative consequences.  Five-word synopsis: Drug brings man material success.

In a moment that almost gives hope to those of us with a sense of morality, Robert DeNiro's character cautions the protagonist about his rapid rise in status, saying that he did not earn it like others have.  At this point I felt like there might actually be a moral to the story, but as the movie continues the word of warning turned out to be hollow; the film scoffs at morality, paints a man who is not good as the good guy, and heaps material reward upon him.  Meanwhile, viewers are shown some rather disgusting violence.

The acting and direction is done well enough, but it led me to a place I didn't want to go.  However, some people will enjoy this fancifully amoral fantasy.

Note: I didn't see the Unrated Extended Cut, but I can only assume that it is even worse than the theatrical release.

When my husband brought this movie home he had to talk me into watching it.  Once I watched it I was hooked.  I love the thought of the possibility of a drug that can make someone use every part of their brain.  I have recommended this movie to numerous people who all enjoyed it immensely.  Overall this is one of my favorite movies!!!!

Fascinating, unpredictable movie. This is one of those great movies where you are at a complete loss trying to guess the plot in advance. Deftly written with great twists and turns, going from grand highs to devastating lows and danger. Bradley Cooper proves to be quite the actor as well; he plays both the burnout unmotivated writer, to brilliant rich guy on the move equally well.

I would have preferred they stayed a bit longer with the great successes he was experiencing in the beginning...the downhill path Cooper has is fast, steep, and dangerous to say the least. DeNiro's casting and role is perfect as well.

To some, I might be exaggerating, but this is, without a doubt, the BEST film I have watched in all of 2011. And trust me, I watch dozens of films in 2011, many of which were great too. With this film, I have become an indesputable fan of Bradley Cooper, and it's my favorite actor after Jim Carrey and Adam Sandler. I had seen the digital copy elsewhere and loved it so much, I had to buy the BluRay, which I got for an awesome price during Black Friday.

The story is unique. I don't remember seeing any other film where the male lead happens to take a drug that would basically make him a genius, and does it in such a way that it's just thrilling. Not much else to say, I straight up loved this film.

RECOMMENDED

"Limitless" reveals to us what can happen when we achieve our full potential. In the case of the movie's protagonist, he uses an experimental drug to achieve the results. We get a glimpse of all that's possible when his mind starts to function at full capacity. However, we also get to see the negative side effects of relying on chemical enhancement. The negative side effects are the primary drivers of the drama in this movie, as well as the attempt to mitigate those effects. This establishes the crux of the whole movie: Who succeeds in the end, the man who takes the drug, or the drug itself?

The basic idea - loser comes across the ultimate smart drug and uses it to create great success... and failure. That's not a plot spoiler because it's summarized by the lead character in the first three minutes of the movie. It's a different twist on drug abuse that's not really discussed much. Sure, lots of college frat boys are taking ADHD drugs to try to cover up for too much partying when exams roll around. But if we can make drugs that warp our minds as much as LSD, why not make a drug that improves acuity by a similar degree? It makes you wonder if Big Pharma does have such a drug but keeps it under wraps while they feed us more Viagra. Overall, the movie was nicely paced. The music was great. Acting was good. It would have been nice to see more of De Niro but I guess the movie wasn't about him or his character. If you liked A Scanner Darkly (or preferred the Phillip Dick book), you'll find this movie a fun "romp in the park." Not nearly as deep but also much more approachable.
I love the actors in this, but couldn't finish the movie.  I tried twice and each time got bored.  I really wanted to like it, it sounded like a good idea, but wasn't very well done in my opinion.
Studios have decided that you MUST watch fifteen minutes of previews in order to watch this blu ray. Don't support this practice by purchasing this movie. Torrent it instead.
I thoroughly enjoyed this film because it allowed my imagination to go crazy and wish I had that pill now and 10 years ago. LOL!

Very nice story, good actors and two or three intelligent plot twists. The book is awful, the film is outstanding. The concept could have been developed further but the final result turned out to be quite good, anyway.

Tale of an underachieving writer type whose life begins to unravel which leads him to try out an illegal drug called NCT that basically takes you to 100% of your true brain capacity and catapults the main character's meteoric rise to success. He finishes his novel in but a few days and proceeds to make stock investments to take care of his money problem and of course win back the girlfriend who left him at his low moment of self sabotage. The drug has some side effects which black him out and make him not so successful and sort of explain some of the plot holes but not all of them. Of course, the problem with having a story like this in which you take a pill that puts you at 100% brain capacity is that there are so many possibilities that some segment of the movie audience is going to object to the actions of the main character. You're better off just going with the story. Based on the Alan Glynn 2001 novel DARK FIELDS. The budget was $27M and it made over $161M at the Box Office. Wowza. CHARACTERS/DIALOGUE: B plus; STORY/PLOTTING: B; INTRIGUING IDEA: B plus to A minus; WHEN WATCHED: mid January 2012 (streamed); OVERALL GRADE: B plus.

Gets up and going right from the start and like the Energizer Bunny, keeps going and going right up until the very last minute. What a great ride! Love this flick. Great story, special effects, directing and acting.

Also, every time I watch this and it gets to the part where he is cleaning his apartment after taking NZT for the first time THE SOUND SHUTS OFF!!!  WTF??  If I rewind it back then the sound comes back on.  This happens every time I watch it!  HEY - YOU DONT WANT PEOPLE TO PIRATE MOVIES??  Quit selling CRAP!
I saw this in the theatre with my children.  We really liked it.  Bradley Cooper is so freakin' hot, hot, hot!  This was a very interesting concept movie.
Very entertaining and interesting film, if somewhat implausible.  These guys really know how to put together an excellent production.  Actors and production staff made a great effort.

Did not know what to expect although had seen trailer for this in movie theater way before released. Liked it. Well paced, acting is good and plot base is believable. Not a super action, car crash, explosions movie but still very enjoyable. Recommend.

I guess my overall problem with this movie was less about what it's advocating/suggesting and just more about the story in general.  As a story, this movie failed to grip me from the very beginning.  I felt no connection to the main character.  When we first meet Bradley Cooper (at this point, I can't even remember his character's name, and I just finished watching the movie about 5 hours ago) he was down and out.  In the course of five minutes, we see him struggling to write a book (even though he oddly enough already has a contract for what I believe is a fiction--not normal), he loses his girlfriend, and we are told that he lost his first wife several years ago.  But that's it, within five minutes, he gets a drug, his life gets better, and all he ever has to struggle for again for the remaining 139 minutes is to maintain the steady dosages of the drug.  His entire life turns around pretty much.  He gets his girlfriend back, he gets millionaire friends, completes his book, begins trading stocks and hedge funds once he realizes that his life's calling.  I mean, at no point, are we really given a chance to feel for this guy.  As Robert de Niro most aptly pointed out, HE DIDN'T EARN ANYTHING.  He didn't put in work, he didn't put in effort, and yes, we are supposed to believe that his life sucked for a time before all of his success, but we barely see that.  There are a couple of instances where we are led to believe that he almost loses it all--the murder investigation, the sudden sickness, the thugs beating him up, but really, he doesn't even come close.  He's definitely not the standard protagonist and in 144 minutes, the writer's could not even develop his role so as to make him more human, more accessible, and somehow reconcile the person he became with the "bum" he once was.  If they had, I think we would get a character worthy of a movie.  As it is, this character isn't even worthy of a bedtime story.

Girl dumps boy for not living up to the potential she saw in him. Boy uses drug to not just live up to but surpass that potential. Complications follow. But really, money is the ultimate aphrodisiac so you know as long as he can keep the money coming he can keep the girl (plus a few bonus trysts along the way).
I enjoyed this much more than I expected I would. Moves at a quick pace and definitely held my interest.
There were so many fantastic movies in 2011, but this is the one I keep going back to again and again.  What a great story with great directing and fantastic acting.

Limitless is original and different yet it does not make sense,I am not a fan of things that do not make sense. However,Good acting some DeNiro added in here and there and a little item that makes it all Perfect or so it seems. The Camera work is great but at times annoying and would make some nauseous but the story is different from what is been churned out now and while it does not make sense(It is a movie though)It is worth watching.

Spoiler Ahead!

I watched this with my friends in the theatre. The plot and the acting keep me interested from the beginning till the end. It's about a wonder drug that enable people to recall everything they saw. They're able to master everything such as a new language after looking at TV for a couple of minutes! Wow! Of course, people can get rich quickly with that ability. The best thing about this movie is the amazing camera tricks. They effectively portray the effects of the drug that happen to Eddie, the main character.

It also frighteningly shows the side effects of the drug. It strongly reminds me drug is a death trap. In the end, Eddie said he had got rid of the drug. However, he still had that magical mental ability. I doubted his sincerity. The ending was open because it did not give any clue that Eddie's statement was true.

In short, it's one the BEST movies released in 2011 in terms of thriller.

Limitless uses an interesting concept you've probably have seen before: Is there a cure all for our limitations, an "easy button" for life?. For Eddie Morra (Bradley Cooper), this comes in the form of NZT, a pill that is designed to enhance a person's cognitive abilities and focus.  Eddie, a failed writer, sees that the possibilities are infinite, as he can become twice the writer he was, and has a newfound mental power that enables him to react to all life's dilemmas. Limitless takes this premise and runs with it, making it a quick-paced, thrilling ride, putting you right in Eddie Morra's world.

The director uses both visual effects and quick-paced action along with an engaging script to come up with a film that works and keeps you glued to the screen. Eddie, an antihero or sorts, is a likable loser who drinks too much and has trouble finding jobs, the ability the write, or finding his place in life.  When he begins taking NZT, the positive results are instantaneous--he writes a book in a few days, he plays and wins at the stock market, he impresses his ex-girlfriend, he feels a newfound success. However, as you could probably guess, as things are going too good for Eddie, that things will eventually blow up in his face. He realizes that there are scary side effects and a dark nature to NZT, and that former users have had mysterious and sometimes violent ends. Things really take off as Eddie tries to figure out his world and the effects of the drug amid the chaos of being pursued by thugs.

While Limitless does many things well, the ending, in my opinion, was a bit too safe, anticlimactic and tidy, and it's probably the weakest part of an otherwise engrossing film. It's the kind of ending that doesn't really leave much of an impression, rendering the resolution typical and predictable, when it could have been more memorable. Still, Limitless is an exciting experience, an action film with an interesting look at the benefits and negatives of "artificial" intelligence in the form of a pill.
Holy crap. Unfeasible meets unwatchable. It's difficult to find write 20 negative words that can describe how stupid this film is. Tough to care about anyone in the film.

The recent 2011 film `Limitless' is not only a fast paced, technically mesmerizing cinematic experience but surprises the audience with ever an accelerating journey into contemporary modes of power, persuasion and mind expansion. I was sucked in immediately, but lost a little interest halfway in when it appeared to be drifting away from the internal, speculative "hidden powers of the mind" theme and evolving into a mundane action/adventure film. Fortunately it readjusted one last time for an unexpected and memorable finale that left me with a smile on my face. Loved the soundtrack too!

Its a good movie. And you get a different perspective when you see the alternate ending.

However, These DVDs need to offer a different aspect Ratio for different buyers. Its annoying to have a NEW DVD in Blu Ray used on a wide screen TV and you STILL (STILL) get horizontal black bars on the screen. Some of us get the full picture with a 185:1 aspect ration. This one is delivered with a 240:1 aspect ratio.
Do not show this movie to your children, it WILL encourage them to take drugs. Seriously, I am not sure what the moral of the story is! Waste of time and money...

This movie had a pretty interesting plot- original and controversial (taking drugs to find success).

I think the characters could have been developed a little more. We didn't learn much about his on-again, off-again girlfriend, or even DeNiro's character.

Overall, there was enough suspense to keep things interesting, and a few plot twists to make you think. The ending was a little "blah," but the movie did not disappoint!

(Sorry for the sparse review, but there are already so many that expound on what I've already said, it just seems repetitive to write it all out again!)
Is a fantasy film, not fiction, the idea about a pill is very elemental not apport nothing new, has a good Art Director, good actor.

Believe it or not, I could not find the Blu ray version of this movie anywhere! So why didn't I think of Amazon sooner, not only did I find it, I got it at a amazing price.  This is one of the best movies I had seen in a long time.

Bradley Cooper is Eddie, a writer trying to write but cannot write a word. He is a straggler who is bankrolled by his girlfriend Abbie Cornish. However, she gives up on him as well and he bumps in to his ex- brother -in-law, who gives him a pill that harnesses the intelligence of the brain in such a way that the ordinary man becomes exceptionally gifted and is able to perform at many many times his normal aptitude. So you know what can happen from this point, Eddie becomes famous and bad guys start stalking him. Eddie also realizes that too much of the pill can turn him in to a monster. Bradley Cooper finally manages to carry this film on his shoulder, Robert De Niro has a small role but is okay as usual. Great film to watch on a day when you have nothing to do and simply relax. 4 stars. 11/26/2011

There are a lot of movies about drug addiction, and most try to be emotional heart-brakers.  This one tries to be the opposite.  Built around the experience of a failed author who comes across a drug that improves mental performance, this movie comes across as an action flick that is part crime thriller, part drama and part adventure.  Bradley Cooper was a perfect fit for the role; I could not have seen anyone else act his part.  However, some of the scenes seem forced.  For example, his borrowing of a large amount of money from some unscrupulous folks was totally against character.  Also, for someone so smart, he does the absolutely stupid thing of storing all of his drugs in one place.  Overall, a better-than average movie.  The premise is good, along with the acting; however the script could have done with better editing to clean up some logical errors.

Thoroughly enjoyed this suspenseful 'what if' movie.  It pushes the bounds of what's possible with the fast pace, slick style, bold irreverence, escalating tension and edgy editing.  Watch it and get caught up!

When this came out, I saw one or two previews and blew it off.  Finally, I took a shot on it and I came away satisfied.  Limitless is Johnny Mnemonic with American Psycho minus the mediocrity and murder.  Ever see Strange Days with Ralph Fiennes?  Yeah, this is the movie it was supposed to be.

Bradley Cooper, in his most tolerable role yet,  is a mumbling post modern hippy trying to finish a book.  One day an old friend gives him a skittle on steroids and he becomes a superhero Einstein, stealing a nooner with the landlords woman after impressing her with law speak. Great concept, mostly great execution.

Director Neil Burger employs an inventive use of vanishing point zooms to draw us, and our Walter Mitty through the vortex of a speed freak with a bottomless diet of knowledge.  It's a fun ride all the way through.  The disappointments are few.  Robert de Niro  feels superfluous as does the ravishing Abbie Cornish.  Also, despite the hook and "speed" of the narrative, it feels like we get short changed in the end as if the story doesn't go as far as we want it too.  The element of risk dissipates and the finality plays the safe card.

Bah, it's still great stuff and Andrew Howard steals this one as the Ruskie shylock.

A great movie that will leave you in suspense till the very end! I loved the whole idea/concept, and the amount of tension built, made for 2 hours of anxious nail biting!

  Overall a great thrill and recommended to all who enjoy a good action-packed movie!

  Have fun watching folks!

 - Ryan S

Bradley Cooper does a fantastic job in this film. He is virtually in every scene and he is magnificent at holding the attention of the viewer as this strange tale unwinds. This is not small feat because watching someone for two hours can certainly become a drag if the actor or actress is not able to constantly evoke energy and tension as the narrative develops. I have never seen the guy in a film before but he certainly convinced me of his skills in this film.

The story is witty, a story of a deadbeat writer who can't write and who has run off his girlfriend, played to perfection by Abbie Cornish. I have never seen this lady in a film before but she holds her own. Back to the story - Eddie Morra, the dead-beat writer, is offered some pill by his ex-wife's drug dealing brother. The pill makes every synapse in the brain work overtime and thus every thought, fact, and memory are now accessible at lightening speed. However, like all drugs, what goes up must come down. This film is a nice parable about the actions of drugs, particularly the message that nothing is free in life. Before long, Eddie is involved in more dangerous situations than you can count, and this provides much of the drama of the film.

I gave the film 4 stars instead of 5 because the ending was too nicely wrapped up. I would have preferred an ending that was as dirty and gritty as the majority of the film, but hey, some folks like their movies to end in a nice pretty tied up package. It is a highly entertaining film with a highly talented actor carrying the story from beginning to end.

The concept is intriguing: take a pill that massively increases brainpower to the extent that you far surpass nearly everyone else, and then seen how your life changes because of that.  The benefits are impressive: rapidly finishing challenging projects, learning new languages with ease, making big money by discerning patterns no one else can, becoming irresistible to attractive women, and generally moving up in the world.  But of course there's also no free lunch, since other people (including bad guys) will take notice and want a piece of the action, plus the pill itself turns out to be addictive and has serious side effects, including potential death.

While I enjoyed the exploration of this concept, and the acting was also pretty good (De Niro stood out), my one complaint is that the plot construction seemed somewhat haphazard in an amateurish way, which really took away from the believability of the movie, so I found it hard to stay fully engaged.  For this reason, I have to deduct one star, but I can still recommend the movie to people who have fantasized about what it would be like to be super smart.

This is an excellent film!  Limitless is well-acted, has a very interesting plot line, and makes creative use of cinematography and special effects without going overboard.  It's also extremely suspenseful and contains enough plot twists to keep you on the edge of your seat right up until the very end, where it leaves you feeling sad to see the credits roll because it was such an exciting ride.
