Well, after seeing the movie for myself, I had to comment. I'm sure you've been reading through some reviews and seen some pretty high marks, and some shockingly low marks as well. Well, having read those very same reviews myself, I'm here to comment on them and the amazing quality of the movie and not the PREVIEWS, NOT Fox's cntrol of the screen menue!

For those of you that find your user interface very important while watching the movie (such as being able to skip previews before the movie even begins) then you should avoid all of Fox's new DVD's and Blu-Rays for the rest of your life and stop whining about it.

For those of you who really want to see a great movie, see this movie. Don't let the bad reviews of a few people ruin it for the rest of you. Someone on Amazon and Netflix gave this movie a 1 star rating just because they couldn't handle being without a couple buttons on their remote long enough to watch the movie itself.

So, from someone who actually WATCHED the movie and SAW it all the way to the end (some of them didn't even give this movie a chance) WATCH IT for yourself, and give it a shot. I found it to be very engaging and of a higher caliber than most of the other movies that have come out within the last few years. I've literally just finished watching it, and I'm about to add this kid to the cart for my home movie library. No, it's not for everyone, but if you like fast paced plot, WELL DONE plot, based on a book sort of plot, then yes, you need to see this movie.

Can't say I love Bradly Cooper but the chicks sure do dig em.  Wasn't very excited by this but I have to admit is was one of maybe a handful of films this year that you didn't walk out of wishing you had your money and time back.  Fun, fast paced film about a super pill which unlocks your inner genius.  Big Bad corporations are fighting to get a hold of this wonder drug even with some depressing side affects (death!).  Cooper is fun, quick witted and carries the film.  Good performance from DeNiro but only slightly more than a cameo.  Good Friday night movie...
Love this kind of movie.  Very imaginative, creative, and well-done.  Wish there were more movies like this.  I'm hoping for a sequel.

Try watching this movie when you're sleepy or already half a sleep, cause last thing this movie'll do is bore you. Amazing plot, mind blowing and unpredictible turns in the story. If you're sick of movies where you can tell what's going to happen 15 min before it does, watch this! Highly recommended.

Bradley Cooper (HANGOVER) is terrific as aspiring journalist Eddie Morra caught in the grip of an extended - perhaps permanent -- writer's block.  But then he meets the "former dope dealer" brother of his ex-wife who gives him a sample of NZT, what he claims is a radical new "FDA approved" drug that allows one's brain to not only recall but make sense of everything it has ever absorbed.

On the drug, which Morra discovers is not FDA approved, he turns in his previously blocked but now brilliant manuscript in a few days.  In record time, he parlays a few thousand dollars into millions on Wall Street.  And then he catches the eye of ruthless billionaire trader Carl Van Loon (Robert De Niro) and nefarious individuals who plan to force Morra to broker the biggest deal ever and will do anything to control the drug and keep it from Morra unless he does their bidding.  Morra ends up in a desperate race with gangsters and the police to maintain his supply of NZT until he can figure out how to survive what seems like an impossible situation.  Oh yes, the drug has dangerous, debilitating, perhaps fatal side effects.

None of the plot described here begins to convey the intensity of the movie experience and the surprises along the way.  Director Neil Burger has a sure hand on theme and the clever visuals of the work wonders in conveying the "limitless" sensory experience.  The Blu-ray has an alternate ending, an unrated extended cut of the movie, a director's commentary and more.

This wasn't an amazing piece of art by any means, but it definitely had entertainment value, and the special effects and acting were awesome.  I thought the plot sounded really cliche, but it was actually different from what I expected.  They were still able to turn it into a unique, compelling storyline that had you into the movie at every moment.

I think everyone sometimes wishes they could just take a pill like Eddie and unleash all types of strengths and create new perspectives.  I think the concept of, "it's already there, it just needs to come out" has always been interesting when it comes to the human psyche, and this movie definitely explores that.  I also appreciated that there was no major lame plot twist just for the sake of being shocking.  It didn't need it.  I wasn't thrilled with the ending, but I won't put any spoilers on here!

Definitely something to watch just for fun, and as a bonus, it's also a bit thought-provoking.

This is such a terrific movie!  It's fast paced, exciting, some parts will have you on the edge of your seat.  First movie I've seen where Bradley Cooper played the lead.  He's VERY good.  Robert DeNiro has a great cameo.  A really different type of story.  Very cool.  Highly recommend this film.
Agree with other reviewer: this one is a sleeper.  One of the best written and produced science fiction films I've seen in a long time.  This one is a must for anyone who enjoys a solid thriller.
Bradley Cooper is amazing. The movie stretches your imagination and is pure fun. Keeps you on your toes. Highly recommended.

I'm not sure what to make of the fact that my search on Amazon only returns the Unrated Extended Cut of Limitless. I watched the "rated" version, so I'm not sure what was different.

Anyway, this is another movie that drew me in with its intriguing premise...a pill which facilitates/compels you to use 100% of your brain rather than just the small fraction that we normally use. It's intriguing to this about what to do with that unlocked potential ability.

I felt like Bradley Cooper's character was well developed in such a way as to give us a good juxtaposition of just how far this pill could take you. I was glad it didn't take on a "superhero" aspect a la 'Matrix' or something like that, but it was cool to see his interactions and reactions to difficult situations. I also loved that the movie drilled down on the consequences. As the adage goes: With Great Power Comes Great Responsibility. It was cool to see everything fall apart due to his lack of respect/planning for the power he held.

I felt like the movie really expanded on the idea of how much each of us could truly be capable of if we would just stretch ourselves to try and use our full potential (even without a magic pill). Taken back down to us "normal brain users", there are good messages there...we should stretch ourselves, we should live up to our own potential, we should set high expectations and try to achieve them, we should set goals, we should plan, we should get off our butts and do something worthwhile. This was a fun and thoughtful movie with a subtle underlying message.

3.5 out of 5 stars

"Limitless" is an entertaining thriller that keeps you interested, not because of its plot which is certainly interesting but not very convincing, but because of the strong acting from the lead Bradley Cooper. Here the "Hangover" star plays Eddie Morra, a wannabe writer who has been dumped by his girlfriend Lindy (Abbie Cornish, "Sucker Punch").

On the worst day of his life, Eddie gets "NZT-48" - a new drug that enhances brain activity to its maximum level. One tablet will make you not "high," but "clear." Using the drug, Eddie begins to reinvent his life, but as you know, some drugs can cause side effects.

"Limitless" does not take itself too seriously. The NZT is a narrative device that is too convenient but serviceable enough. Robert De Niro appears as a business tycoon, and Anna Friel is effective as Eddie's ex-wife, but it is Bradley Cooper who carries the suspense film throughout, as a desperate protagonist you just cannot hate. It is regrettable that director Neil Burger ("The Illusionist") didn't come up with a better way for Cooper's character to use such amazing abilities. What Eddie really wants to do is not always clear, and when it is clear, it is not very interesting.

The thriller keeps a good pace. The film also has stylish visuals, and the story is unpredictable, but enjoyable as it is, "Limitless" suffers from some loose ends and major plot holes that could have been easily tied up and fixed. (How many tablets does he have? What really happened to the woman at the hotel?)

"Limitless" is a slick thriller with a few suspenseful moments, but works most effectively as a showcase for the acting talent of the star Bradley Cooper.

Every year I buy about 10 movies I've never seen and generally enjoy about 90% of them.  This year my miss is LIMITLESS.

While I really enjoyed the premise and thought the entire plot was well thought out this one missed me for in the execution.  It's like the creative team felt they need to push the envelope in cinematic technique.  I think the movie could have stood on it's own without that.  THe acting is solid (though you can tell its as filmed quickly in some scenes).  This movie could have been great and could have been a repeat watch in my household.

Sad to say that I cannot recommend purchasing this movie.  While I am certain that some people love it- don't purchase just because you've seen the previews and like the premise.

The main thing I like about Limitless is that it wasn't predictable and it has great replay value. The movie is entertaining, exciting, tot at all boring or typical of the slew of "cookie-cutter" movies that are a dime a dozen these days. I definately agree with the synopsis of it being this year's sleeper. The tunnel vision effect might annoy some momentarily but it's a minor quibble. Watch this. It's worth my money and I'm glad I bought the blu-ray.
Very entertaining flick and some great visuals.  The movie makes you think about the possibilities. Great acting and interesting characters.

this is a pretty good movie. Bradley Cooper does an extremley good job at his role. this movie is really good. the actors and the story are awesome. one of the best movies i've seen this year. if you have not seen this movie then i recommend that you do

Good premise although not entirely true it does provide a good representation of "what it would be like" to have complete use of your faculties. Good power play and visuals. If you look for it you can even find some good inspiration to get your things in order and try to "be your best".
A very well done film.  I really enjoyed the twists and the acting.  Intelligent premise and the actors did a great job making the viewers believe the story line.

This may have made a better tv episode of something for an hour because the movie doesn't know what to do with itself in the second half.  We have everything we need to know and understand happen in the first half.  The rest just meanders with that same material.  Our lead character takes a super drug which lights up the dormant part of his brain so that he is using all of his brain all of the time. The hitch is that you have to keep taking the drug.  He inherited the stash of his late, murdered brother-in-law.) But while he is taking it, he becomes fabulously rich and increasingly powerful.

This is very slick, stylish and visually beautiful for the first hour and then that aspect is exhausted.  Unfortunately, the remainder of the movie becomes the standard action flick with the hero trying to stay alive as various unsavory characters want the drug.  I think if the lead had been made into a scientist, who decided to experiment on himself with his own new drug, this would have been more believable.  It is scarcely believable that his scraping along brother-in-law had his own huge stash of the drug laying around and that no one else knows about this drug.
Good quality movie, compeling characters, strong story only a few minor plot holes, otherwise a pretty good show.  Unique story and fun to watch.

I loved the plot concept. But it's execution was kind of stupid. It could have been a lot smarter than it was. It leaves me with many questions to ask.

1. Why did Eddie Morra (Bradley Cooper) not pay back the Russian loan-shark? He made millions of dollars super fast (completely legally), and the loan was only $100,000. If the drug made him smarter, why did he forget to do this? More than half of his problems in this film would not have happened had he remembered to do this. But did he really forget? He couldn't have. Maybe he thought he could get away with the money without paying him back? Who knows?

2. Why did he not immediately try to ration his limited supply of NZT? Or better yet, why didn't he immediately seek out a scientist to either make more of the drug or find out how to reverse engineer it? He starts deliberately taking more than he should. He should have known the bad effects that would have occurred.

3. Why did Eddie allow Carl van Loon (Robert DeNiro) to convince him to continue working for him when Eddie politely told him his plans to go his own way? The only argument van Loon had was "I know this business and have more experience." Realistically speaking, this argument is useless considering the superior mental power that Eddie had and the superior rate at which HE was making money compared to van Loon.

4. When Lindy took the NZT to escape the trench coat assassin, she immediately knew how to do parkour? She doesn't look like she's in shape to be running and hopping over everything. No drug makes you good at parkour without practice.

5. Similar to note number 4, Eddie becomes a master fighter because the NZT helped him remember fighting videos he watched? Anyone who tries to do what they see in martial arts movies without any proper training ends up dead. No drug will make you fight better unless it makes you move so fast that the world is in slow motion and you're not.

This film should have been much smarter.
This movie is so lame and dumb that I felt stupid for renting this. ROFL to those who said this is a thought-provoking or smart movie.

Overall a very good concept-however with lots of "Holes"... It does spurn the "Imagination"- & Brings a new meaning to-" Nothing good comes easy.... If it does...WATCH OUT"!!!
I found it to be fairly entertaining - yet fairly slow @ times.... Enough to almost lose interest.
The acting was overall "A" rated..-how can You miss with the that cast?!
If You like the actors... You'll probably enjoy the film- if nothing else- for the Fantasy aspect.
 Don't expect it to change your life.....
  Dr. W
too bad the dvd copy of the film was not included. overall the package arrived on time as expected. bla, bla, bla

THIS YEAR'S BEST MOVIE! A PLUS. THEY SHOULD MAKE A SEQUEL. I HAVE SEEN COUNTLESS MOVIES AND THIS ONE WILL NOT LET YOU DOWN1` I WATCHED IT 3 TIMES IN 48 HOURS BECAUSE IT'S THE BOMB! CONRATULATIONS BRAD COOP. I DON'T EVEN LIKE HIM BUT HE DID A WONDERFUL JOB!
I loved this movie and the plotline.  It kept me on the edge of my seat.  I watch it over and over again.
Finally an original movie idea that could have a hint of truth behind it. I loved Limitless fast paced, good action, and get this a good story. I'm looking forward to watching it all over.

This is an interesting concept with too many problems within.  Here is a pill that makes you smart yet somehow Cooper always has problems!  He didn't know he was out of pills until he grabed the last one.  Never occured to him?  He forgot to pay his loan shark back with his millions of dollars of profit?  The worst of course, is that he successfully predicted a texting driver would crash into another car.  Out of all ways and means to prove this guy is brilliant, the movie has to resort to complete random chance.

Not to say it was terrible - it was entertaining but too many scenes threw me off.  It's a problem to have a genius run into problems he could have easily avoided.  The final scene is Cooper chewing down on De Niro when in fact that speech should be geared toward the audience, not some small character we don't care about and can't connect to.  There were not enough connections to everyday events (people) to engage us.

It's enjoyable but I wouldn't say go out of your way to see it.

Great movie about how awesome life would be if you fired on all cylinders all the time.  What would life be like if you could remember everything, always be able to access information exactly when you wanted it and had no fear?

Very interesting concept, filmed in a different way too.  It took a moment to get into the film and the way it was directed/filmed but it was good.  You have to really pay attention and follow along, and if you do I think you would find this a very good movie.

I'm on the fence about Bradley Cooper in general, but his work here and in the A Team is excellent.  This film has an original idea that is kind of out there but they make it work.  Appearances by DeNiro class up any film.  Great effects and action filled story keep you interested.  Rock on Mr. Cooper.

Great movie! I've shared it with all of my family and friends. I would recommend this movie to people who are interested in the way the brain works. If you are interested in what your life would be like if you were fearless, super-intelligent and endlessly charming.
I was disappointed in this movie.  I expected more in the plot.  It sort of dragged in the beginning and I was lost as to where it was headed.

The movie kept you on your toes.  If only this was real.  The movie was interesting and entertaining.  Bradley Cooper and Robert DeNiro performed well together.  If you like fictional movies I would recommend this movie.  The movie was never slow, it moved at a good pace so it was easy to follow when going back and forth with what was happening.

This movie is original,exciting and different. It stars Bradley Cooper(an upcomig star)as Eddie Morra a down on his luck writer, who seems not to be able to do anything right. By chance he runs into his former brother-in-law,who turns him onto this wonder drug pill that enables the mind to access 100% of it's power, instead of the normal 20%. The next thing you know he becomes a superstar on wall street, makes a lot of money, gets some fame. But of cousre their is trouble ahead, their are some side effects to the drug,and Eddie must deal with with mobsters and others that want the pills. Their are some twists thrown in, it all turns out to be a very entertaining movie, a mix of drama,suspense and action.
I reccomend this seller and this product.  The movie was awesome, it arrived on time and in the condition stated.  I would deffinetly purchase more items from this seller.

My expectations were low for this, and so maybe I am over-rating it, but I was very pleasantly surprised. I was glued to my seat the entire time, and appreciated the unique storyline, in a sea of predictable alien/robot/superhero action films. Bradley Cooper plays a down-and-out writer, actually a bit of a loser that can't quite get it together, who stumbles upon a new off-the-market drug that maximizes brain potential to such a degree that he (and other who have possession of it) can completely transform their lives. He becomes a 'master of the universe' - first writing his long-delayed book in 4 days, and then turning his sights to the financial markets. The action involves his battles with others trying to steal his stash of drugs, his attempts to understand the side-effects, and to figure out how to extend his limited supply. In the meantime, he is attempting to impress Robert DeNiro who plays a financial king, as part of his path to wealth and power.

This is really the first time I have taken any real notice of Bradley Cooper, and I think he does a great job here. He is better suited for quirky, somewhat twisted roles like this one than standard leading man roles I think. Robert DeNiro is always fun to watch, and the supporting cast does what they need to do.

There were minor weaknesses in the plot - how did Cooper's loser writer character ever get a book contract? Why isn't there some kind of adjustment period to achieving maximum brain potential? How is this drug kept secret except to a very few? etc. But overall, it delivers action, is not predictable, and Bradley Cooper gives it his all, so I think it deserves a 5-star rating.

I like sci-fi films and 'Limitless' fits into the genre as one that seems plausible or at least presents itself that way. The film features a great performance from Bradley Cooper with some help from resident acting guru Robert DeNiro. Interesting visuals give the film a fresh style and the quick pace makes for a story that is never boring. A unique film that blurs the lines between drug addiction and useful medicine and makes us think if there are reasons to take a chance on such a dangerous gamble.

This movie was a real surprise to me. A great plot with some terrific action and good acting. How come I never heard of it? The movie studios really baffle me with their promotions of awful movies like LA 2010 while never promoting a solid movie like this! Bradley Cooper just made the jump into the great actor category where DeNiro already is. Abbie Cornish's role could have been bigger. She was terrific! Highly recommended if you like intelligent action movies!
I found the story to be Intriguing.  Better it was the cinematography that really one me over.  Dont' expect a great plot, just go along for a wild ride.

LIMITLESS was one of those movies I really wanted to see after I saw the previews.
The premise of the film was great and insightful.

The first half of the movie lived up to the expectations and set the proper tone for what this sort of experience and capability would be like.

But the second half of the movie seemed like it was written by a different screenplay writer and led by a different Director.
The second half of the movie really faded into a sort of comedy and all the tensions and initial build-up was lost.

In the end, the film failed to fully capitalize on its initial brilliance.

Add to that the fact one must overlook the obvious logic flaws in the movie .....

Foe example, if this drug was able to make your mind so sharp and able to learn and master new skills like Classical Music and 3-4 foreign languages in only 2 days, would it have not seemed obvious to spend 3-4 days learning Chemistry so you could synthesize the mind enhancing drug yourself and thus not be reliant on somebody else for a supply ?

A good premise and entertaining movie that did not quite reach its potential
I had heard nothing about this movie, all I can say is WOW!!! One of the best movies I've seen in many years.  It's a real thriller, it had me and my wife on the edge of our seats.

I wasn't sure about this movie at first but took a chance one night when I was in the mood to watch a movie. I don't know what I wasn't sure about because this movie was really good and I loved the concept. It had me intrigued throughout the entire time. The beginning was awesome, where it showed Bradley Cooper's character as a bascially lovable bum who is given the chance to use 100% of his brain with a pill. Am I the only one who noticed the Robert Smith hair the morning he awoke with tell-tale signs of the drug having worn off( I loved it)??

Bradley Cooper did really well in this movie. I thought he was just an okay actor before, nothing really going for him except his looks. He proved me wrong with Limitless.

Limitless is an entertaining ride through the ups and downs of a smart, but drug-addicted writer/loser (Bradley Cooper). Cooper is the one that makes the whole concept actually seem believable. His is simply awesome in this movie. The other characters are forgettable to me, not because they are terrible, but because Cooper takes the stage. I don't normally buy movies on the day they come out, but this is one of that I just had to have. One of this years best films. It is stylish, smart, and limitlessly entertaining.

It's hard for me to explain what my title is indicating but you really should approach this movie with an open mind; a mind of a "WHAT IF?" mentality. I loved it from start to end. The Alternate ending wasn't to get excited about and I'm glad they left it out the release. Overall, an awesome movie that I'm sure will be a classic.
Bradley Cooper!!  Okay, the story was interesting.  Almost too long but they got away with it.  Would have been disappointed if we paid movie theater fees but for a rental, we liked it!

An intriguing concept forms the plot for LIMITLESS:  a drug that enables its user to utilize 100% of his brain---the possibilities are limitless.
The film is highly involving as star Bradley Cooper convincingly leads us on a whirlwind journey through financial success and drug dependency and the inevitable withdriawal.  You don't know whether Cooper is a hero or a villain.  Does his dependence inspire or disgust us?
Robert DeNiro is effectively sinister as a corporate giant who wants to use Cooper to implement his long term goals.  Lovely Abbie Cornish isn't given a lot to do but she gives it her best.  The drug-induced states are cleverly staged, director Neal Burger using color and lighting to establish the drug's effects.
LIMITLESS is ultimately Cooper's film and carries it well.  With his piercingly blue eyes, swaggy confidence and unflinching honesty, Cooper proves there's more to him than THE HANGOVER.

WOW.
What a great and nice movie that was.
I liked everything.
I was not expecting this movie to be that great, i wanted to watch it though because the story was kind of interesting.
I was not deceived by the awesomeness of this movie.
I can't go into details since i liked every single part of it.
Unlike the BIG BLOCK BUSTERS CGI MOVIE this movie had only one thing that made it so good, it's the storyline.
I hate writing so i will just finish by saying .....If you hate it you don't have any taste for movie and you should go back to your basement.
thanks bye bye.
I loved this movie. It had a wonderful plot and of course Bradley Cooper is easy on the eyes! I love love the ending. Too cool. Would definitely recommend it.

Bradley Cooper has come a long way since "All About Steve". I actually enjoyed his acting and the interesting script. I even like the ambiguity of the ending where you are not quite sure where the truth ends and the lie begins. A few predictable scenes, but a ride worth taking. I recommend it.

This movie reminds me of what happens to wallstreet apprentices. The main character stumbles into something that seems like an opportunity. But as he gets deeper into it, he sees the danger; but is so far in, he can not get out of it. Of course, there is a love interest that makes everything more dangerous for him and her. It becomes a balancing act, one that he has to win at if everything is to turn out all-right. My husband and I liked this one.

This is for sure a better entertainer of the 2011 lot. Bradley Cooper suits the character well. Though fans like me would expect more from a great actor like DeNiro. His role in the movie was short and not so powerful as his introduction shows. With so less characters, the director has managed to keep the pace which is a commendable effort. This movie gets its place besides other brain based thrillers like Inception and the like. Go watch it if you like fiction.

Contrary to popular belief, we humans do use virtually 100% of our brain.  But if you can get past that as most people do believe we use 10% of our brain, you will enjoy this movie.  Basically the point of it is, what if you became 90% smarter than you were before.

Limitless is based off the 2001 book called "The Dark Fields" by Alan Glynn.  The story centers around Eddie Morra(Bradley Cooper), a wannabe writer who somehow has a writing contract, yet he hasn't written one word of his expected novel, he is dumped by his girlfriend (Abbie Cornish), who as she put it was his "cleaning lady" and his "bank".  So basically Eddie is a washed up bum.  But then as a chance of fate, he runs into his ex brother-in-law, Vernon,(Johnny Whitworth) a drug dealer who gives him a pill nicknamed NZT that he says will enhance his creativity and cause him to use 100% of his brain.  At first Eddie seems skeptical but decides to take the pill.  Surprisingly the pill works, and Eddie becomes so smart he is able to write his entire novel in 4 days.

Eddie comes to find Vernon to get more pills, and Vernon tells him to get his laundry and bring him breakfast first, Eddie finishes the errands and returns to Vernon's apartment to find the place torn apart and Vernon murdered.  Knowing whoever done this must have been looking for Vernon's stash, Eddie searches all over and finally finds the pill and some cash inside the oven.

With his huge supply of pills and some starting capital, Eddie is able to find secret formulas in the stock market and make a ton of cash in just a few days.  A big investor, Carl Van Loon,(Robert De Niro) becomes very interested in him.  Eddie feels he is on top of the world, but there are still some problems.  The drug is highly addictive and if he stops taking it he realizes he loses his intelligence and he becomes very sick.  The drug has strange side effects such as loss of time, and black outs.  Also, a strange man keeps following him, and even tries to kill his girlfriend when she has the pills on her to bring to Eddie when he is suffering from NZT withdrawal.

As the movie progresses, Eddie has to deal with all the people that want his drug, and he has to keep finding ways to get more.  He discovers billionaire investors that made all their money because of this incredible drug.  He pays scientists to figure out the ingredients and make more, so that he has a limitless supply to support is limitless intelligence.

This movie caught my attention because of the idea that you could be so incredibly smart that you could become the richest person on the planet, the president of the United States, every woman would want you, the possibilities would be limitless(hence the name, but everything comes at a price, and at the end of the day it would a drug you were taking, and we all know the consequences of drugs.  I'm now interested in reading the novel which I may review next.  But if you haven't seen this movie yet you're in for a real treat.

Limitless Starring Bradley Cooper Robert Deniro and Abbe Cornish in this Unrated Extended Cut Thriller about a burnt out Writer Bradley Cooper discovers a top secret pill that unlocks 100% of his brain's capacity as he acquires mind bending talents that bring him big money beautiful woman and limitless success but at a dangerous price and one the drug is very addictive and the other borrowing money from the wrong people with Exclusive Alternate Ending Theatrical Version & Unrated Extended Cut & the only difference between the Unrated Cut is 139.01 with more detail in one of fighting scenes towards the end and Theatrical Version 138.14 , The ending can be a bit confusing at first cause acts like hes on the smart pill but says hes off it and on the alternate ending by continuing taking the smart pill can work out a way to get off it without any side affects , Special Features : A Man Without Limits , The Making of Limitless , Audio Commentary with Director Neil Burger , Alternative Ending and Digital Copy a Good Thriller picture and sound .

This movie starts out kinda slow but if u stick with it ur really gonna like it. It is a little long but by the end ur gonna wish azt was a real drug.lol The only bad part to this mocie I can c is the horrible tupee they put Bradley Cooper in at the end of the movie.
Enjoyed this movie with the family, I had no problem with it - it worked well and both case and disc were in good shape.

The character (Bradley) eventually overcomes the side effects and finally put it to good use. The drug works only if you're already smart. It doesn't work on uneducated thugs or single-minded tycoons. It works on ordinary average people who puts their education to good use. Another thing I liked about the character is that he didn't try to con everyone. He just made an honest money although going through the loan shark was a dumb idea. I liked De Niro's role and he really shines at being a bull-headed businessman. I also liked the ending where the character tweaked the bugs out of the drug and improved it so it becomes permanent. He could've been an FBI profiler solving tough cases or a doctor finding cures for deadly disease instead of a Senator but of course, that's just me.

PS - he reminds me of a TV show 'Chuck' where he fought a bunch of losers by remembering what he saw from an old Bruce Lee movie.

A waste of a good idea. The chance meeting and the plot that follows are poorly developed. If this was better produced it would have been very entertaining. Perhaps someone else will get the story and make it a good movie.  Meanwhile, you should pass this one by.
Brilliant in every way.  Bradley Cooper is a very dynamic actor that pushes his limits in this film and comes up flawless.  A sequel would not be a mistake.

From start to stop this is the noisiest film. Occasionally there are a few known pieces of music from classical masters. Yet for the most part it is obscure pieces of music overwhelming the dialog. Occasionally there is musicales spot where they still play jingles or extremely loud sounds of glass breaking or footstep noises. If you can get over the noisy background the primes is pretty good. I would not want to presume on telling the producers how to improve this film but it is really too much like those soundbite documentaries were they do not complete a thought before moving on to the next thought. Basic story is Eddie Morra (Bradley Cooper) a going nowhere would be writer who stumbles in a situation where he obtains a substance that allows him to utilize parts of his brain that were previously unreachable. Now we are off and running. Where is the substance coming from and are there any side effects. Watch and find out. If you can get over the noise there are a few fun spots where you can put yourself in the situation. The Dark Fields by Alan Glynn
Limitless had a lot of tempo changes that I found boring.  The plot was pretty thin and did not keep me glued to the screen as most good thrillers will.
Great movie for those who want to be limitless. Excellent cast, script, and plot. Bradley Cooper and Robert DeNiro are terrific.

When I start this movie it launches into all of the previews, as it normally does.  However, It is completely locked so I cannot skip, fast forward, rewind, anything.  I have tried every button on my Sony BD player and the only ones that work are the stop, which starts all of the previews again and back which starts the individual preview again.  It is somewhat infuriating that this movie is completly locked down so you can not even speed through the previews.  The movie is ok I guess.

This Blu-Ray DVD locks the user not only from being able to skip the previews but it also locks the user out from being able to fast-forward through the previews. So, every time I put this DVD to watch the movie from where I last left off, I am forced by the stupid studios to sit through the same 10 minutes of FORCED previews that I can't skip or fast-forward through. This forced lock by the studio not only keeps customers from being able to enjoy their movies but is extremely disrespectful.  EPIC FAIL!

I really enjoyed LIMITLESS with Bradley Cooper, Robert DeNiro and Abbey Cornish.
This is a very sharp & smartly done modern morality tale which raises the question...
If you were just an average Joe Blow, who was barely just getting by, living your life in a haze
of less than spectacular stimuli, opportunities, and results...or as a great person once said,
"In quiet desperation"...and the circumstances came along where you gained access to a magical drug
which could make you super sharp, more aware, intelligent, well-versed and worldly...WHAT WOULD YOU DO?
Would you go the cliche' route of the FOOL'S PARADISE??---Doing as much mindless partying, sleeping
with the most beautiful people you could encounter, scamming to get as much money as you could, only to rip
through it in no time flat, only to scheme to get some more?---Or would you practice moderation and use your
new found gifts with benevolence, and for the betterment of not only yourself, but others?
The combinations and scenarios of what we MIGHT DO if we could have access to these powers are endless!

Bradley Cooper's character is living just such a marginal mediocre exsistence at first...
Until fate brings him into a world of amazing highs and privilege, but also mind-numbing lows and consequences,
which will test the metal of his very soul, and all who lay in his wake.
This movie is filled with thrills, intrigue, face-paced dialogue, plot twists, and plenty of action throughout.
Of course, there are always negative effects to anything that we do.
That whole yen v.s. yang thing...but ultimately, it's all about balance in life, right?
I watched this all the way through twice, back to back, and I really enjoyed it, and would recommend it to anyone.

Robert De Niro plays an old lion, who made his bones the old-fashioned way...
He had to reach through the flames to get it. He's a grizzled New York high level player
whose nobody's fool, and is not one to cross. He sees this new, seemingly-so-together, young lion,
(Cooper) as someone who could be a possible strong ally, as well as a possible threat to all he has built up.
The relationship between the two is one of mutual admiration, and mutual distrust at the same time.
The last scene between them is KILLER!
I will be buying this UNRATED EXTENDED VERSION within the week... ** 5 Stars ***

this movie was not at all like i thought i can't say it was bad i just thought from the parts they showed on tv that this movie was going to be better.  yes i would watch it again but not my best watch.  thanks movie house

The premise of this movie is that the protagonist discovers a drug that allows people to use 100% of their brains. This premise of course, exploits the common misconception that humans normally use only a small fraction of their brains. But in reality, the only people who normally use a small fraction of their brains are people with severe brain damage or those in persistent vegetative states and also Hollywood execs that green-light garbage like this. There should be some expectations, of course, for an audience to suspend their usual healthy dose of skepticism known commonly as the "willing suspension of disbelief." But audiences shouldn't be expected to become complete cretins just to enjoy a movie as seems to be the expectations of the film makers for this movie. The film leaves several logical loose ends. One keeps asking oneself why if the drug may be taken without many serious side effects as the film's ending hints at isn't everyone on the drug? for example.

Unfortunately, this movie did not make for a very interesting cinematic experience. It could have been interesting if it focused on the ethical issues associated with such a drug for example but it took the low route and tried to make a conventional action thriller but containing little entertaining action and thrills. The common cheap plot devices to increase suspense are employed but no novelty either in the form of the overall plot or suspense are employed. The lead actor played by Bradley Cooper often seems robotic (even when he wasn't supposed to be strung out on the drug). This is a very forgettable movie with asinine dialogue and mediocre acting at best.
it pretty much sucked. the only evidence we have of his "limitless thought" is fighting and saying random stuff about the stock market.

Bradley Cooper and Robert DeNiro in the same film? That got my interest. And a premise about a human with limitless abilities? Also intriguing, though I worried it would turn into a spinoff of the recent flood of superhero movies. Instead, "Limitless" is more down-to-earth and more layered.

Cooper's character is an author with a book contract, but no ability or discipline to focus that talent. He is losing sleep, relationships, and peace. When he bumps into his former brother-in-law on the streets of New York, that all changes. He is introduced to a new drug, and soon he is flying high on the new energy and focus it gives him, allowing him to access the full potential of brain--but at a cost. If he stops taking the drug, he gets sick and discovers that even death could result. More immediately, though, there are others after this illegal substance and the effects it can produce.

Mixing stylistic elements of "Fight Club" and story elements of "Wall Street," this movie spins off into its own interesting take on the limits of the human mind and its potential for danger. It also comes across as a veiled expose of the prescription drug industry. Don't get me wrong, though. "Limitless" is not a message movie, at least not overtly. Overall, it's a very entertaining, somewhat thought-provoking, and ultimately violent tale of the good and evil that await us in a society where access to all sorts of drugs becomes "Limitless."

Eddie Morra (Bradley Cooper) is having a good night. The best in a long time. An old friend turned him on to a new favorite. Nothing better than a dealer who's high....Be high, convince Eddie to try! And Eddie Morra does indeed try.

Turns out this highly addictive new favorite is an experimental drug that Eddie's old friend has somehow gotten his hands on and there are some rough and tough people that also want their hands on it. So when Eddie winds up with a significant stash of this new favorite these rough and tough people now want to get their hands on Eddie. But Eddie has an advantage over his foes you see...the new favorite unlocks the full (superhuman?) potential of the brain, which according to the movie humans only use 20% of. Ah...well that explains why I spend so much time writing reviews for no pay!

Limitless was a pretty fast paced entertaining movie. Limited special effects are very good, and there are some very cool camera special effects at the start of the film (that actually get a little monotonous by the end of the film). While the pills that Eddie was taking were easy to swallow, a lot of the plot line was not. I mean for starters, this would be a pretty breakthrough, highly secret and tightly secured and scrutinized discovery. So let's say even if someone very high up in the pharma company manufacturing the drug was interested in the intentional or inadvertent leak to the public of the drug in such large quantities, it would not be as easy as Limitless makes it seem like it is. But if you don't think too much about this and some other plot line flaws and inconsistencies, you have pretty good movie here.

So the movie all in all is a pretty fun ride and we see Eddie become an addict of perhaps the most irresistible narcotic to ever be discovered. If you don't think that you would ever get addicted to this drug, you can't understand a user's mind. You could try with your books and degrees, but if you let yourself go and open your mind I'll bet you'd be doing like Eddie. And it ain't so bad.

The plot of this movie is simple. A man takes pills that unlocks 80% of his brain that regular humans don't use. To me, it's a very catchy plot, because who doesn't want that? The story picks up right off the bat, and for the first 30 minutes or so, it moves quite nicely. However, it fall into a slump for about 40 minutes, where, to tell the truth, I was bored out of my mind, and was thinking about shutting it off. However, it redeems itself with an entertaining chase through the park, and a house robbery. All in all, it was "OK". 3 stars is good enough for this film

There are movies made with fantastic premises that you just want to see. The previews make them out to be something new and original and thrilling. And then you see them and think wow...that was...okay. Unfortunately most movies just don't live up to the hype. Such was the case with LIMITLESS, a good movie but one that just wasn't great.

Bradley Cooper stars as Eddie Morra, a down on his luck writer with one mediocre novel published and a case of writer's block. Just when he thinks things can't get worse, his girlfriend Lindy (Abbie Cornish) dumps him. Walking down the street after she turns him lose, he comes across an old "friend", the brother of his ex-wife (of one day) Vernon (Johnny Whitworth).

Back in the day Vernon was a dealer and Eddie wants nothing to do with him. But he seems cleaned up, cleanly dressed and doing well for himself. During lunch he passes a new drug to Eddie, tells him that it's about to be FDA approved and that it will help him. The drug helps the person taking it use their entire brain potential. While its said human's only use perhaps 20% of their brain, this one kicks in the entire 100%.

On his way to his apartment Eddie takes the drug thinking he has nothing to lose and runs into his landlord's girlfriend on the steps. As she berates him for not having the rent, the drug kicks in and he not only talks his way out of the chastising but beds the girlfriend as well. The drug actually works. So much so that Eddie changes his lifestyle, writes the book he was working on in 2 days and it turns out to be perhaps one of the greatest books ever written.

Then he comes down off the drug. He finds Vernon to get more and Vernon now has Eddie where he wants him, doing his bidding. Eddie sets out to get Vernon's dry cleaning only to return and find Vernon with a hole in his head and the apartment trashed. Whoever showed didn't get what they came for, Vernon's stash of the drug. But Eddie figures out where it is and becomes a regular user.

He gets his life back on track, learns languages in less than a day, wins back his old girlfriend and starts a new life for himself, all with this limited supply of pills. He cashes in on financing, goes to work for his broker and is introduced to one of the top moneymen in the country, Carl Van Loon (Robert DeNiro). This leads to a job with Van Loon and the chance to turn what he's learned into millions if not billions for the company and himself. It also gives him access to possibly having someone make more of the drug.

But it all comes at a cost. The loan shark who gave him the money to invest originally now is taking the drug and wants more. And whoever it was that killed Vernon is trying to find him as well. Eddie has risen from the worst position possible to the highest and yet still has problems, just different ones, ones that could cost him his life.

The movie has a terrific look to it, clean and sleek and fast. When the drug kicks in we look through the eyes of Eddie as well as from the outside, seeing that things move so much faster in his mind that the world seems to be in slow motion. And while Eddie's brain increases in capability, he doesn't seek to do harm to anyone but rather intends to do nothing more than take care of himself and those that matter to him. But as they say the best intentions...

Cooper does a great job, shifting in acting modes as well as appearances from the down and out Eddie to the more successful one. He carries off the performance well and is completely believable. Cornish feels as if she's just there and DeNiro makes the most of what is essentially a supporting role.

For all the great story that is found here it just comes off as a decent flick that doesn't completely fulfill it's potential. Perhaps that's just my expectations not being met, but I just felt that the movie was nothing more than another in a long line of films that are entertaining but not memorable. And honestly, there don't seem to be that many being made any longer.

Most will find the movie is an enjoyable film that will keep you guessing until the end. And the ending itself was one of the best I've seen in some time. So if you're looking for a solid movie to rent this week then by all means give this one a try. It may not stick in your mind forever but it will give you a pleasant night watching a movie.

Nowhere did I see in the product description that this BD would only play (forced) on region code A bluedisc players, so it will not play on a region code B player (like e.g. in Europe). This is the very first overseas BD which I could not play, BTW. The digital copy with DRM just for the PC is not a real compensation, since it lacks a) BD quality and b) BD goodies. And due to DRM it will only play in Windows Media Player or iTunes.

In the meantime, I know from various forums that FOX is one of pretty few studios forcing this customer unfriendly BD regional code.

So, customers from overseas: refrain from buying FOX media in the US if your player does not support the BD region code A.

It will certainly influence my buying habits. No more FOX. Pity.
Excellent acting and dialog. I wouldn't put this movie in my top ten, but I can safely say I will watch it again in the near future.

The problem with making a movie about intelligence, is the lack of intelligence possessed by the people making the movie.

A modern day version of the fairy tale Jack & the Beanstalk, the hero is given some "beans" by some stranger which he "plants" unthinkingly. The beans take him to a castle in the sky where unbelievable riches are simply lying around for the taking. Hold on though--there's a giant that wants nothing more than to grind his bones to make his bread!

The parts that aren't inspired by the tale of Jack and his magic beans are the women in his life, and the anti-drug and moralistic themes that somehow lose their way as the film winds to a close. And these are what ruined the film.

Eddie's ex and current girl both try the brain-boosting drug. The ex shows the terrible effects of taking too much brain food, but at the end, conveniently limps out of his life while dispensing words of wisdom on dosage and how now, he has to keep taking the pill "or else you'll die!" His girlfriend tries the drug, pulls off some running/parkour that would impress Will Smith and Tom Cruise, but feels that, even after having, what I am assuming is superintelligent sex, that the drug is "bad." Her reason? Because it's not really you doing these things. Lame.
Why do the women always have to be typecast as voices of reason? Ghosts of Christmas Past rattling chains, yet at the same time, not really giving any actual lessons.

The anti-drug message of the film, which is just that the pills have a downside: Take too much and you'll black out while fighting multiple dudes on a subway--and where all those seemingly wasted hours zoning out on action movies and youtube videos actually pays off, and you just might actually kill a supermodel. None of this hits home as the murder is never resolved, and you're taught that moderation is they key.

The biggest downer, however, is the fact that by the end of the film, the message becomes that the benefits of having full use of your brain, still does not preclude acting like a total tool. Unimaginative writing propagates the already prevalent belief that above-average intelligence is really all about making loads of money quickly and getting a lot of punani. Oh, and becoming a US senator who will screw with people on a global scale.
Wild movie did not know how it was going to go. First try to figure out how they were doing it but when you figure it out blows the mind. Real good movie action non-stop & loved the way it ended.

I liked this movie.  It is a fantasy, although there are resemblances to reality.  Bradley Coopers' character Edward has a writer's block and can't seem to make any progress on his book.  His brother in law gives him a drug that enables him to use 100% of his brain as opposed to 10% or 20%.  If the person was already intelligent, the drug enables the person to organize and access all information in his brain at will.  It also enhances creativity.

There aren't a whole lot of special effects, but the plot is interesting.  All of a sudden, this drug opens up a lot of possibilities for him that did not exist before.

It is hard not to notice parallels to reality with drug addicts: withdrawal symptoms, extra energy, heightened senses, and accelerated ageing of the body.

** SPOILER **
Toward the end of the movie, we learn that he used an enhanced version of the drug that did not have any side effects, and after a limited period of use, enabled him to use 100% of his brain without any further use of any drug.  In reality if such a drug was available, why would anybody not use it?  It seems to me like no-brainer, except if there was any *unknown* side effects to be discovered.

Great acting, great cast, great movie.  Highly recommended.

It's good news for the world that my local apothecary doesn't produce batches of these mind-enchancing pills. Because, no doubt about it, my end game would involve nothing less than total world domination. So it's maybe better all around that it's Eddie Morra what ends up with the almighty brain boost. Dude seems more altruistic.

As LIMITLESS opens, Eddie Morra (Bradley Cooper) - unfocused, unkempt, and rocking a despicable haircut and a sickly pallor - is getting dumped by his more successful girlfriend Lindy (Abbie Cornish). Eddie is a writer suffering one of them horrid writer's blocks, and this is as kicked to the curb as he's ever felt. So who can blame him for ingesting a panacea to his woes - a top secret pill which supposedly unlocks 100% of one's brain power? (Well, yes, you can blame him; kids, don't do drugs, or whatever).

And the pill performs as advertised, a happenstance director Neil Burger couldn't wait for because, on cue, he lets loose his first salvo of hyperkinetic, ridiculously inventive visual effects, translating on screen what Eddie must've been experiencing as his IQ is uplifted (to four digits, natch). And, best believe, while Eddie is under the influence, his perspective shifts to that of a warped, sharper-imaged reality. The film's first half is crazy awesome as we track Eddie's segue from hapless slacker to motivated genius. Eddie now can access all the bits of information that have lodged in his brain down the years. And he does what you and I would do. He lives out his wildest fantasies. He tackles foreign languages and tricky math equations and sordid philosophy. He takes on Wall Street with a ferociousness even Gordon Gekko would admire. He even finishes that book, and it looks to be a best-seller. Now, women are easy gets, money accumulated with the alacrity of belly button lint, respect and admiration raked in like leaves on a lawn. Eddie's meteoric rise in high finance soon gets him eyeballed by a ruthless Wall Street baron (Robet DeNiro). And DeNiro's no match for our guy, providing Eddie keeps on digesting them smart tablets on a daily basis. It's sweet that Eddie would want to get back with his ex-girlfriend Lindy. You like him better for it.

And then the side effects begin manifesting. They aren't pretty. He begins suffering migraines and memory lapses. Director Neil Burger unveils a passage which breaks down one such memory skip, giving us a distorted quick edit taste of Eddie Morra's out-of-body experience. Maybe the best bit in there is when Eddie is accosted by thugs at a subway station, and Eddie uses memory aid gained from watching Bruce Lee films to whup some butt.

And there's a scary Russian gangster.

LIMITLESS is one of them films in which I wasn't sure what to expect, but it turns out to be a really good movie, a highly charged, twisty kind of escapism. Bradley Cooper had been in a bunch of ensemble casts; I think this is his first really lead role, and he doesn't waste the opportunity. He turns in a charismatic, self-assured performance. I think it's key that he's able to keep his character as a genuinely nice guy throughout the picture.

The third act comes off weaker as the plot degenerates to routine chases and  confrontations. And, honestly, the film lost some of its humanity when it went away from Eddie and Lindy's love story. However, the coda - featuring Bradley Cooper's final run-in with DeNiro - brought back the bravado. I'm not sure how faded Robert DeNiro is from his glory days, but I will say that he and Cooper provide some really watchable moments in their scenes together. Mostly, you can't peel your eyes away from LIMITLESS, with its outrageous premise, its imaginative style and high wire act, and its sheer swagger. It's probably okay to give Bradley Cooper more leading roles.

The DVD includes both the theatrical version and the Unrated Extended Cut of the Film. Bonus stuff as follows: audio commentary with director Neil Burger; an alternate and less satisfying ending (00:05:14 minutes long); "A Man Without Limits" - focus on Bradley Cooper and what he brings to the role of Eddie Morra (00:04:27 minutes long); and the theatrical trailer. The back of the DVD case also lists a "Making of LIMITLESS" featurette, except I couldn't find it on the Extras menu.

Whats makes this movie so goos is that there is a good pace to it. Bigger yet, is that the movie really addresses every wild imaginative thing one would think of to do with the powers Edward gains. Really enjoyed the movie!!! Worth watching.

I saw this movie in theaters and thought it was good so I bought it for my Dad's Birthday. I liked it the first time and I liked it the second time, and I would probably watch it again. Edward is going no where fast with his writing career until he runs into his ex-wife's brother who gives him a pill that gives him full access to his brain. The short term effects are great for Edward he's motivated, smart, and gets rich quick...however, like with any drug there are consequences. The action in this movie keeps you entertained and the plot twists are great.

I did watch the alternate ending and I am definitely glad that's what it was, "the alternate" because the real moving ending was much better.

Excellent movie! Well filmed, well performed, intelligent and entertaining. I really enjoyed it.

Question: Where can I buy some of those little pills????

I thought the movie was just o.k..  I agree with other reviewers that the concept is terrific.  Since I'm not an action movie junkie, the concept is what drew me in.  I just have to say, for someone with "limitless" brain power, this guy made some pretty terrible decisions.  Probably the best part of the movie was discussing what we would have done with limitless potential once the movie was over.  Getting involved with a Russian psychopath mobster was not at the top of anyone's list!

I have never written a review, just had to for this movie, that's how good this movie is. Bradley Cooper is one of those great character actors, and he doesn't even look like Ernest Borgnine or Paul Giamatti. Honestly don't understand why he isn't a bigger star with more leading roles. Anyways great story, great production value. Get it now you won't regret it.

I am not sure if I have seen a main storyline with more potential wasted.

So a person with limitless brainpower would use it to make money on Wall Street and run for politics? Really? The imagination of the writers were certainly limited, and that's too bad, because this film had its unlimited potential reach only about 5-20% of its capacity (depending on whom you believe).

This isn't a smart film. It is a trick; a gimmick with no real substance.

There are, however, few saving graces. Bradley Cooper (main character) is very convincing as an actor. I am convinced if he reaches 100% of his acting potential, he would be worthy of an Oscar, and he is far more than 20% there.

Before anyone tries to copy the concepts of this film and make yet an another script of enhanced-brainpower person making riches in Wall Street, then I suggest such person take more NZT 48 and enhance his/her own brain function first.

And how come the brother-in-law gets himself killed? Doesn't he know taking that pill will save his life from assasins? And how come he never gives it to those who want it? I mean it's for sale. Just sell it. But I suppose no one in the writing team has thought of that. More NZT 48 please.

Limitless is a fascinatingly good movie about Eddie Mora's rise to power using a brain-stimulating drug called NZT. The first time he pops this drug, a whole new world opens up to him because his brain is operating at maximum power. Very cool to watch this happen. Even cooler is that there are others who know about NZT and some are using it themselves. What unfolds is a dangerous game of minds to see who comes out on top. Bradley Cooper gives a great performance and so does De Niro.
great movie very easy to watch and enjoy, its a captivating story and lesson anout drug harmful effects on the body, definitely a must see movie!

"It works better when you're smart to begin with," (or something like that). This is one of the great lines in the movie and pretty much sums up the movie in one sentence although for me it goes more like this:
"The movie works better when you're not too smart to begin with," (or something like that).
The reason I say that is because first of all the initial premise of the movie i.e. you can utilize 100% of your brain is flawed. There is no scientific evidence to suggest that we use only 10% of our brains. We already use 100% of our brains! The 10% statement may have been started with a misquote of Albert Einstein. If we didn't then we wouldn't have all these people that are crippled for life after a bullet to the brain or any other brain trauma for that matter since most of it isn't used anyways! Anyways, knowing this I still gave the movie a chance since it seems to be pretty popular so it must still be worth watching I figured.
And it is worth watching for the entertainment value it provides and the special effects.
I really dug how they did the drug effect's. Anyone who has come down off of a caffeine high, smokers high, or any other non natural drug should be able to relate to how Eddie Morra feels and the associated withdrawal of coming off drugs. Although, some of the effects did enter LSD/peyote territory with strange future like flashbacks.
The film did a pretty good job of portraying what it feels like to be considered highly intelligent. Like they say knowledge is power and it's just like in the movie when you are smarter than all those around you first of all your confidence it greatly improved. If someone is trying to kill you as we see with his girlfriend in the park you don't cry like a baby because you see 10 different ways to defend yourself using your brain and instantly jump into action. You become fearless to a certain degree. Intelligence will tell you in 9 out of 10 cases best thing is to run away. That is why the fight scenes with Eddie weren't realistic at all because even if he knew all the moves from reading or watching movies he would still need practice to skillfully execute the moves. It'd be like being able to read music and know how an instrument works doesn't mean you can actually play one! Learning multiple languages was not far fetched since he would have the memory recall and mental speed to pick it up quick. Once again he would not come off as smooth sounding as in the movie unless he lived in those countries learning the language because there are some things you just can't pick up in books. For example, when I lived in Japan I decided to learn the language from a book it was easy enough but when I went out in the street and actually talked to the Japanese they thought some of the stuff I said was funny or archaic since it's not used it everyday speech. I guess a  As we saw with Eddie at a cocktail party no topic is off limits because your superior intellect allows you to store tons of vast amounts of useless but entertaining information. It can come in handy sometimes though like with the law school girl in his apartment complex and yes you are able to recall information you've skimmed or seen on tv years ago although sometimes you do have to dig a bit and it may not be as accurate as portrayed in the movie. The again the thing with being highly intelligent is that others rarely question your information because their limited recall of facts and figures rarely allows them to dispute these vast stores of information in your brain. I didn't find the whole getting laid due to intelligence credible in real life but in the movie Eddie is not only good looking but intelligence so I guess it's a win win situation for him.
The other part I found believe and liked was how the movie showed that even though this guy is now super intelligent it doesn't mean he's going to take over the world nor does it even guarantee any sort of success at all. For example, just like in real life he has to go out and try to find someone willing to loan him some cash to really get his feet off the ground and if he was really smart I can't imagine him going to a shady person for it unless he did the risk/benefit ratio analysis beforehand and even then I don't think any benefit is worth getting cut at the waste as having your skin tied around your head as the Russian mafia guy mentioned. Also, later in the movie the DeNiro character mentioned gave him some wise advice and tried to show him intelligence is only a tiny part of the picture in being successfull in business telling him how backroom deals, networking, etc also play a big part.
Now the downsides to being smart is that you see flaws everywhere and this is how it ties in to this probably being a better movie for those that aren't too smart because first of all you'll fall for the 100% brain thing and think geez wouldn't it be cool to be supersmart? Yeah it can be cool at times like I mentioned but then there are the downsides like the flaws which you try to ignore but cannot since they stick out like a sore thumb. It's just like when Eddie was looking over the documents DeNiro handed him in the limo and right away he was able to see all the flaws and errors. So it's the same when watching the movie. They aren't too bad but the twists don't work too good though since you already know way ahead how things will end.*** SPOILERS ***
For example the lawyer stealing the pills out of coat.
Other mysterious guy coming out of nowhere also taking pill.
DiNiro character asking for favor.
The film started off strong and did pretty good at being consistent till near the end where it seems that the writer got in over their head and so they started inventing stuff to conclude it. For example, Eddie almost killed by Russian mob because he ran out of pills but someone at last minute he stabs guy and drinks his blood and saves himself. Don't know how they left this flaw in film since even Russian guy explained that shooting up drug more faster since it goes straight to brain. Licking it up off floor would be same as swallowing tablet! Even after all this Eddie shrugs off all deaths in apartment as done by previous tenants although if cops even did basic job they would find his blood prints on knife, etc. which would easily implicate him in murders!  And after all these questionable deaths surrounding him he's still able to get himself elected to the senate? Finally, biggest flaw in movie is that we saw earlier in movie that anyone taking the pill would have shortened life and yet he comes out that oh yeah I found a way to keep myself smart without using the pill which isn't fully explained. Then again that's more how real intelligence works there is no off switch like a pill. I guess you need to read the book as someone mentioned to fill in the gaps.
 Finally, primarily because of Western cultures lack of esteem for intellectual values, Eddie Morra wouldn't be so happy and tend to be unhappier than average. I mean he loses his girlfriend and doesn't seem any the sadder compared to the start of the movie!
Speaking of his girlfriend she seemed to be one of the more believable and sane characters in the movie. I mean she basically dumped him when he admitted he was doing drugs and didn't see anything wrong with that and using that to get ahead in life. Sort of like the recent string of steroid scandals. Looking back I guess some people could argue that the movie was just one big/long ad like those you see on television for anti-anxiety, viagra, etc.

What if you could advance the quality of your life by being super-smart/creative/talented with the aid of a pill?  What if the pill had deadly side effects and evil people wanted your stash?  This is an exciting and intriguing film with the talented Bradley Cooper in the lead.  He has an everyman quality that is relatable (although at times he seems a bit of a loser which makes the plot turns all the more interesting).  Abby Cornish plays the girl lead and she was great in this action thriller.  One of my favorite parts was her in the park at the rink - great action chops on her.  Would love to see her in more action films in the future.  I liked this film and found it exciting though at times there were some really scary parts.  Two thumbs up.

The film begins as Eddie Morra (Bradley Cooper) is about to jump off the balcony of his very expensive and tightly secured living quarters. He begins to describe what led him to this extreme situation. The audience returns to when Morra's life has reached the bottom.
Morra is a slacker trying to write a novel while drinking and being lazy. He loses his girlfriend, Lindy (Abbie Cornish), because she cannot take anymore of his behavior and laziness.
Morra was a former drug addict with an ex-wife who has a shady brother. Morra is vulnerable and willing to try anything, except self motivation, to improve his personal and professional life.
He takes a pill from his ex-brother-in-law. The drug allows one to access 100 percent of the brain. Now Morra can remember everything in his past from when he just glanced at documents to personal experiences.
He has the ability to comprehend information in a short period of time. With this new pill, life exceeds one's wildest dreams.
The pill is NZT, and it is to be taken once a day. Obviously, the drug is not FDA approved, so some very serious consequences happen from taking it.
Suddenly Morra, who does not know how to fight and is a mild mannered individual, becomes a person with exceptional mental powers. With his confidence and new found intellect, he begins to climb the ladder of success.
He completes his novel in four days. Before the pill he did not have one word written. The audience takes this trip with Morra as he runs the gauntlet of successes, and repercussions from the drug. Of course, along with taking the drug side effects begin to emerge.
Morra meets Carl Van Loon (Robert De Niro). Loon is a tough business man who is trying to negotiate a business deal with a large corporation. He sees the potential within Morra, so he begins to test his skills.
With all of the drugs people are taking today to sleep, wakeup, relieve pain, overcome depression, feel good, feel bad, and generally go through everyday activities, the pill Morra takes covers everything. However, do not get to excited, it has some very serious side effects.
Life always has its downside. Morra has problems with Russian bad guys, street gangs, and a mysterious lone assailant. Not to mention memory loss from the side effects of NZT.
The film is based on the book entitled The Dark Fields by Alan Glynn. It does have some very dark moments. One scene in particular demonstrates what a person will do in order to stay alive. Traveling in a dark field can be very dangerous. Not knowing what will happen next is an uncomfortable feeling.
However, for the audience it is entertaining and suspenseful. I recommend this film for anyone interested in watching an engaging and original story.
The audience takes the trip with Morra through some very precious moments. Lessons about drugs and how to handle success are dispersed throughout the film. With tense moments and a mystery waiting to be revealed the audience can take the journey without the side effects and consequences. Just enjoy the excursion without medication, but with a plot full of surprises and tense thrills.

Last movie I watched was "Limitless," that one where Bradley Cooper ("The Hangover," "Wedding Crashers," et al.) takes a little pill and becomes unspeakably brilliant. I'd give this movie (in Amazon terms) 4 out of 5 stars.

As for the premise, it's not as insane (or cliched, even, I think) as you might guess. I thought that what would happen would be the typical "Scarface"-ish, poor-hero-starts-from-bottom-makes-it-to-the-once-unimaginable-top-now-comes-crashing-down sort of plot, but really it seems that, despite what I'd say is the impossibility of this ever happening, realism sort of kicks in as soon as the protagonist in this movie gets into action. What I mean is, he starts having to deal with the consequences of his actions as soon as he gets rolling. He finds out pretty quickly that he's gotten involved with some pretty bad people. For example, the man he got the brain-and-senses-enhancing drug from is murdered a relatively short bit into the movie. The pill is dangerous on several grounds; not only does it become apparent that some other people want the drug and are willing to kill those that stand in their way in order to get it, the drug itself has some negative effects on its users. It's basically like heroin: you become very addicted to it very quickly; actually, the biological penalty for not getting more of the drug is death.

What also surprised me is that Cooper's character, for the meat of the movie, never really makes it to the top. He seemingly has the ability to do so, but he has to start off working for other people that have more money than himself. Cue Robert De Niro ("Taxi Driver," "Raging Bull," "Meet the Parents" and, like, everything else), who of course in his later years makes for a pretty intimidating presence, that is, in the protagonist's life. I.e. De Niro's given such a short amount of time on the screen that all in all I felt his inclusion was wasted. He's actually more dangerous-seeming in "Meet the Parents" than he is in this movie. I'm not unhappy that he was in the movie though; I just hope he doesn't become one of those actors who are given these short little bits in movies to provide the film with a little more class and seriousness. (Like Marlon Brando in his later years; it's just sort of the sad evidence that these really powerful stars are beginning to fade.)

The movie took some turns I wasn't expecting, like, for one, the foreign gangster who intimidates the main character into giving him some of the drug, which in turn makes him really powerful and dangerous for a time too. Didn't think his role was going to become that important, but it does. Um, what else. Oh, yes: Hollywood's gotten into this habit of starting the movie in medias res where the hero's on the verge of doing something drastic, at which point it goes back to show you how it all started. This is one of those movies, but for some reason the viewer knows it's not going to end as...ah, flatly...as it initially seems. One last point: all in all some pretty cool and perhaps mild seizure-inducing visuals in this film.

I really don't want to tell you this, but really the only way this movie disappointed me was the ending. It was one of those "We can't really get out of this any other way, so let's just do this because it's safe" endings. And honestly, it wasn't bad; it was seemed to have been stuck on rather hurriedly. At the same time, I can't really imagine how else it could have ended, or at least, what a better ending might have been.  (The DVD features an alternate ending which I haven't watched.)

In short, I think "Limitless" will entertain you for its entire duration.
This movie is so bad, I can't even put it into words.  I didn't even finish it...hit the eject button, and I very rarely do that.

Good guy takes pill,  Bad guys chase and try to kill good guy to get the pill, Good guy overcomes and is super smart and life is good.  Typical Hollywood action movie formula, blah blah....

Lets put it this way or use this for a yardstick, it was not a "V for Vendetta screen play" that really got you to think.

I am glad I didn't plop 12 bucks at the movie theater for this movie.

The movie's plot/story line sucks, ok? It leaves you with many questions that are not answered and then the director takes you on these weird visual tours of Manhattan. Why? I don't know. Probably to distract the viewers from his failures. BUT the movie is entertaining enough to keep you engaged. Those weird visual tours/effects are pleasing enough not to complain much about the plot. Bradly Cooper is a good and promising actor and does his best in this one. All in all, this movie is entertaining and fun to watch....

I thought this movie was quite good. You might have to think a little when watching, but not much, and it's an enjoyable "what if" story to consider. It's not a disposable, blow 'em up action movie. It's not obtuse and self-important like a lot of indie films trying to be artsy. Like many people past their 20s, I find most films quite derivative of what's been done. I thought this was original enough, and may even watch it again sometime (and I rarely watch a movie more than once).

Best line: "It works better when you're smart to begin with," (or something like that).

It'd be cool to have a pill like that, which makes you super smart in every way there is and have such a clear view of the world.. but it does have it's side-effect like every drug out there. Brad Cooper plays a down-on-his-luck book writer who through chance meets his ex-wife's brother who gives him a pill that makes him more so.. and poof, all this great stuff happens... and then the bad stuff happens and he has to find a way to stay on the pills and not die and fix everything and everybody around him. It was a fun film with good visuals.. like the sex scene and everything that he sees.. pure limitless enjoyment..

I really liked this movie, narration and all.  The real question of "what would you do?"  just begs to be answered, and yet not many reviewers have answered it.  I for one, would be very tempted to try NZT, fortunately I would also be too chicken!  But wouldn't it be nice to have be ability to access everything just some of the time.  If you don't get too nitpicky about details, you will enjoy this movie.

So disappointed--seemed like so many people gave this high marks. Bradley Cooper does a great job acting, but the rest is just some tiresome, and rather humdrum, absolutely non-mind-bending stuff. The part about him now being able to access 100% of his brain is actually a very small part of the movie--he gets smart, can do cool things, and things are looking up, and then....nothing. That's it. A little action, no twist, no nothing. The movie ends incredibly boringly and makes you feel like you went through all the rambling storytelling to get absolutely nowhere.

I wasn't sure if I would like this movie but the previews got me interested in it enough to rent it on Amazon Instant.  It turned out to be a great movie.  Good camera work and acting.  I would rated it at 4 1\2 stars but that is not an option.  If enjoy SyFY and suspense you will enjoy this movie.

The Movie
Going into Limitless I did not know what to expect.
